title: Why is mathematics so hard? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think the other answers are good summaries of "why people find elementary and high school-math difficult".  Some people are bad at this type of math (which is not really math at all, but is actually just "calculation" or "numeracy").  Some people can do this type of math, but then find out that they are actually bad at REAL math when they have to learn it in university. School Maths: "Maths" in school is a discipline in which you learn a detailed set of protocols (step by step instructions) and then apply these protocols to a variety of situations.  This isn't *really* math: it is calculation!  I was bad at this type of math.  You can be bad at this type of math by being imprecise/not detail-oriented, having a hard time memorizing things that are structured as step-by-step instructions, having a hard time concentrating on repetitive tasks, having a hard time doing mental arithmetic, finding the subject too boring to invest any time in, having a sense of fear when studying math/expectation of failure.  I fit 100% of the above descriptions.  If you are also like me: don't be disheartened!!!  This is NOTHING like any math you would do above linear algebra or multivariable calculus!!!  Take a class in discrete mathematics (probably the easiest proof-based class, at least at my university) to test the waters and see if you are bad at mathematics or just bad at calculation!  I'm doing a PhD in applied mathematics-ish field now, so there you go! Real Maths:Real maths are much cooler than calculation!  You have to think creatively to solve problems.  In a lot of cases you need to think about how one problem "maps" onto another. Answers are often clever or elegant.  (There is some essay about how if schools taught music like they taught math, then you would spend 12 years learning how to transcribe musical scores and draw all the notes correctly before ever playing a single song.)  People fail at this level when they realize they aren't creative enough to come up with solutions to problems or if they struggle thinking about abstract things.  There are usually many many ways of approaching the problem, and some people can't think beyond the next few steps and often go off on a futile path.  Also, these fields tend to be poorly taught, so you have to be self motivated.  Finally, a lot of people who were the best of their class when they were taught calculation give up when they find themselves in the bottom half of the class, because they never had to work hard in math before and feel disheartened. Engineering Maths:In applied math fields, you don't need to solve any equations by hand (or at least very rarely).  You usually just let the computer do the calculation.  Instead, the important part is being able to have an intuition about equations.  This takes skills like mental estimation (guessing, not calculating), being able to understand how to describe the behavior of a system in terms of a category of equation, being able to mentally approximate the results of a model, and being able to reason about cases where your model would fail.  As a basic example: say you have a line y=ax+b.  You need to have the intuition to know that 'a' determines how fast the graph goes up and 'b' determines where the line will intersect with the axis.  People who struggle with this type of math are people who operate too mechanically, instead of taking a step back and thinking "does this make sense". People who are not good at visualizing graphs in their head might also struggle.   Therefore, there are different skills involved in different types of math.  If you are bad at "school maths" don't get disheartened!  You might still be able to become a mathematician or at least use math in your field!  Don't let calculation scare you!

Mathematics requires an ability to study in complete isolation without getting lonely and without getting discouraged or distracted. There is a self-esteem issue, when you read something and don't understand, you feel worthless and stupid, and these blows to the ego must be shrugged off, and you just try again. It's catastrophic to the ego, because the set of stuff you can prove and other people can't is empty nearly all of the time. So irrationally inflated ego is psychologically useful, because you are going to be constantly confronting your own undeniable, quantifiable, stupidity. Irrationally inflated ego is generally associated with young males. Mathematics is also anti-rewarded by society, in that the more you study it, past a certain point, the less competent you will be at social stuff, like getting a date, because your brain will just keep getting rewired by the math, and you just get objectively smarter, and pretty soon you can't talk to anybody except other math people, because people don't understand you or find you boring, except for a small contingent of mostly young males. So by studying math, you are basically making the decision to work very hard to earn less money and be more socially awkward. So all the people who want political power just don't study it. But why would anyone study it? It's because with mathematics, there is permanent and irreversible progress--- it's been a long continuous punctuated revolution since the 1350s with no equal, except perhaps in the sciences. So you see that progress is possible in an objective way--- it is now easy to prove things that were hard or impossible even 50 years ago, and there's nothing people did 100 years ago that we don't find ridiculously easy to do today. This will go on forever. There is something else that is hard about the mathematics, which is that the pedagogy is terrible. You just can't learn it well in school, because the folks teaching you don't know the history of the field so well. There are also sticking points where mathematics contradicts intuition, and there are exactly two of these, both related: * Godel's theorem: people get discouraged by the idea that there are "unprovable theorems". The resolution to this is to understand the theorem, and know that it isn't saying that there are objectively "unprovable theorems", rather it is giving you a procedure to make axiom systems stronger, and it is perfectly reasonable to assume that all reasonable theorems become provable at some point. This is mathematician's theology--- all arithmetic conjectures will be resolved by a sufficiently large ordinal.* Continuum issues: these are the continuum hypothesis, and well-ordering the reals, and the non-measurable sets. These things are resolved by learning forcing, and by understanding the computational perspective that denies these questions having objective meaning, unlike arithmetic statements. These things were the critical issues for me. There was also some resistance to categories, but the theory there is sufficiently straightforward that you can learn it even if you hate it, and after you learn it you stop hating it. There is another issue of nonuniqueness. There are always many ways to prove something, and people have their own favorite way. So you try to prove things your own way, and you might fail, and someone else does it another way. Maybe your way is better. But sometimes people lose their own creative spark by reading too much about other people's ways. But sometimes people lose their focus by not reading other people's proofs. So who knows what's best here. Generally it's easier to learn mathematics than it has ever been, and it is much better today than 20 years ago, thanks to plentiful internet resources. In a little while it should be easy enough to make mathematical literacy (like understanding everything up to the 1950s) a reasonably universal adult skill. That will make certain progress in society, since there are certain logical fallacies, like gambling, that mathematically trained people don't make.

People find maths difficult because it is inherently difficult. Or- the time to realize one doesn't understand Math is much lesser than any other discipline.  I've graduated with degree in Mathematics & Computing alongside completing various courses in humanities- economics, literature, sociology. Nevertheless I'd prefer encountering a new topic/academic work in the latter for one in maths requires much more endurance and struggle. Why? Because Mathematics is too difficult to relate to. (I mean advanced mathematics, not basic arithmetic) Comparing to a subject like music, history, literature- we tend to have some ideas or opinions regarding them. Although it may bias our reading, it eases as well for it helps in association. Contrarily when we sit with Maths, we're dealing with something entirely new whose practical implications in our daily life are hard to imagine. If we draw a hierarchy tree, Maths would sit atop as it's concepts get used in 'applied fields'. The farther anything moves from reality, the more difficult it becomes to comprehend.  Even after studying advanced maths for 5 years, I'd struggle to define topology, while I can voice opinions on state-of-law, events in history and implications, intent of writers through protagonists primarily due to the subjective nature of these subjects. If I state "World War 2 was won by Germany" then I am wrong, but any further discussions on the topic "Was US right in bombing Japan?" to even the most extreme question considered "Was Hitler doing the right thing" can have diverse opinions. Although these views maybe kiddish, there is a place for them motivating students to pursue further for they can connect with it. Contrarily the objectivity of Maths makes it much tougher. Everything has a definite answer. Is "Hausdorff space compact?", "Is this system deterministic or probable? If the latter, what is the probability?" There's no "maybe it's probabilistic system". There's no place for 'opinions' and those who missed the basics of the subject would fail to understand the successive things entirely. So if one can't understand compactness of spaces, how would one answer if Hausdorff spaces are compact? (When I say difficult, I mean the concepts not the computation-which follows a methodical approach). Burden of proof increases the difficulty- no statement can be accepted without conclusive, irrefutable proof.These follow a sequence of arguments (theorems or axioms). In each step, one may find themselves drifting further from reality.   Any signs of reality? Most of my comparisons have been based against social sciences. However if we compare against sciences like physics, chemistry, medicine- still maths stands as more abstract and incomprehensible. We maybe able to relate to pulleys and resistance circuits more easily than epsilons & deltas primarily because we can see the former with our eyes. Similarly- flora, fauna, our human body- their tangible nature makes it more intuitive than maths. In the end, media-coverage also affects our subconscious understanding. This makes social sciences easier- basic level familiarity with it. If we'd more coverage on science-issues we'd have found them relatively easier. If media focused on proofs and abstraction more, maybe we'd found Math easier- but of course we want a life closer to reality, not away!

It is merely my humble opinion, but one I’ll back up with an article showing that there is at least one other with the same opinion. Mathematics (and, by extension, science) has become difficult because we are not explaining the philosophy behind mathematics and science when we learn. Furthermore, we are trying to explain something which another author here (please help me find the quote) says something along the lines of it being a big upfront investment that takes a long time before the payoff can be seen. Now, we can show small examples of payoff immediately (calculating a pocketbook), but with the big payoffs (descriptions of scientific concepts and computing) being so far removed, it’s easy to lose sight of why someone should learn it, and therefore, the demotivation some may get, makes it appear more difficult. And the demotivation part is important. Many kids are interested in learning things, but somewhere down the line they feel that they are not smart enough, or they have an experience that leaves them frustrated with an authority, or something is taught to them in such a way that it gives them no hope that they are learning anything beneficial. So, I’d like to get further into the root, and the philosophical and psychological reasons for this. First of all, logic may seem intuitive and obvious at first, but the application of logic (which mathematics ultimately is) actually requires a lot of thought. Sometimes the results of applying logic give us things that are intuitive, sometimes things that aren’t immediately intuitive, and sometimes things that are paradoxical by appearance. However, we don’t teach philosophy. We don’t teach formally logic the same way we do math, and then expect them to use such logic in mathematics. We don’t really get into what differentiates the formal sciences from the natural/social sciences. We expect students to believe that mathematics is the study of numbers (it’s isn’t - or rather, the if it is, it’s because the concept of numbers is FAR LARGER than anything they can imagine, but we don’t have a clear definition for that word). We have ways that they can put math in action, but we expect students to: accept they are learning it for the sake of math itself (which, the analytical reasoning skills ARE extremely important)accept that they may or may not use it in their daily lives (even though many will use things they don’t think they will, and won’t use things they think they will)accept that there are valid use cases for almost all mathematics they will encounter, up through the undergraduate level, but we either make the stories too unbelievable, or don’t bother to find a diverse set of uses for ithave an intuition of the subject without seeing such a use caseYou can see that items #1 and #3 conflict with #4. PS. (this was edited in) I wanted to add that many students tend to get stuck on existence. Philosophically, ontology (the study of what is meant by existence) is a difficult subject. When we learn about negative number, and numbers like 0, and imaginary numbers, some students get stuck on existence. We can and should always provide physical interpretations of any concept where we can, but should always be clear that using mathematics is always about the interpretation, not the ontology (which I think is probably a much clearer difference between applied and pure math). Existence has a meaning in mathematics (it’s a quantifier), and we have now seemed to taken the route that if it can exist, then it probably does, and we should stop focusing so much on the ontology in order to study it. The ontology is a great philosophical discussion, but it isn’t required by mathematics to find uses. (Richard Muller's answer to Do imaginary numbers actually exist, and is there any physical quantity that is actually complex?)  Ultimately, I’d like to say this: mathematics is the subject that is the most rigorous (matter-of-fact and exact in speech). It requires precise definitions, precise explanations, and doesn’t take anything for granted. Not everyone teaching mathematics has been taught properly, and we expect them to teach students properly and without demotivating the students. However, it’s not difficult, it’s just foreign at first, and anything foreign can be learned with effort and experience. If you are having problems learning from a teacher, supplement your learning online. If it is not the teacher, maybe you should sit down and ask for other ways of seeing the problems you are having (new views and interpretations on things are a big part of mathematics). If it is some trauma that has turned you off, unfortunately “getting back on the horse” is the best and only option (probably after discussing the event with a counselor, or another math teacher you can trust). Ultimately, get help!!! Mathematics is not done in isolation, and learning mathematics should not be done in isolation either. Start a joint study group. Get a (non-judgmental) tutor. Also, don’t treat mathematics or science skill as if it’s some measure of your intelligence. Sometimes people mature in these skills at different rates, and sometimes they go through spurts. Sometimes, the children that did the best in high school do the worst in college, and vice versa. Sometimes the subjects you failed become your favorite subjects.  I’ll reiterate here. Early mathematics is more difficult to teach than it is to learn. We have to give definitions, but too intuitive, and people get lost thinking that the intuition is what matters. If it’s too rigorous (precise), it’s boring and turns the students off of the subject. It requires patience and persistence on the part of the teacher, and is especially more so when there is a diverse group with cliques that understand quickly, and those that take more time. It requires understanding how students think, and refining that understanding as generations change. It requires appealing to things that make them laugh, things that make them think, and things that make them motivated. It requires positive critique that doesn’t demotivate the students. It requires doing all of this while ensuring that the students understand the subject well enough to make high marks on the tests that will ultimately be the judge of the teachers themselves.

I've struggled with this my whole life. I'm one of those who gets it. But as a math teacher, I have to figure out why people don't get it. Here are some of the conclusions I've found though both anecdote and looking at research. Math is cumulative. Students are often used to learn and dump. Learn it, test it, forget it. Math doesn't allow you to do this. This is also a nightmare for students who have been absent for a long time or have a crisis, like parents who divorce, a relationship gone bad, or a long medical problem. Not to mention what happens if they get a horrible teacher one year. If this happens in any other subject, you can have success the following year. With math, you really have to fill in those gaps before moving on, but most students don't, and with one-size-fits-all curriculum, it's hard to get those gaps filled. (As a side note: If your kid struggles in math, or missed a bunch of school, I recommend intervention early, rather than late.) It is, by nature, abstract. Math is intentionally abstract. The idea is to create abstract tools that can be used in a wide variety of contexts, but this abstraction trips a lot of people up. When you give some people specific hands-on problems, they can solve them. When you confront these same learners with abstract ideas, they can't see the trees for the forest. They can't make the connection between an abstract idea and the specific scenarios they would apply this abstract idea in. Good teaching can get around this, to a degree, by building an abstract idea through a series of specific examples rather than the other way around. Concepts are sometimes introduced at inappropriate times. Different minds develop at different rates. There are milestones that have to be reached before some concepts can be fully understood. One of the reasons that people hate fractions is that some have to learn and use them before their proportional reasoning is fully developed. One reason people hate Algebra is that they have to learn it before their abstract thinking is well developed. Some minds are ill-equipped to do math. Some have better spatial reasoning, some have better logical reasoning. Some have non-math related issues like dyslexia which can be a barrier to learning it. It's really best to avoid this kind of thinking though, because again, development happens at different rates, and just because you don't have as much ability doesn't mean you can't develop a lot. Just because I'll never be an Olympic marathoner doesn't mean I can't increase my endurance considerably by running more. It's hard to do under emotional strain. Any task is hard to do under emotional strain, but whenever you're hyper-emotional, it's near impossible to think logically. This is why test anxiety is multiplied when applied to math. I also have students all the time who just broke up with their boyfriend or girlfriend, or just found out their dad has cancer. Those folks have a hard time doing logical tasks, even if they want to. Math can't be faked. In liberal arts, there aren't as many objective standards as there are in math. If you don't believe me, look at the quantity of liberal arts degrees versus the quantity of STEM degrees. STEM degrees are hard, because you have to know what you're doing, and if you don't it becomes immediately obvious. There are objective standards in other fields, but they aren't always as binary (you know it, or you don't) as they are in math classes.

Anything can be difficult if it's boring. There are certainly a lot of reasons, but I think these lie at the core:  For most sane human beings, math is an incomprehensibly mind-numbing and entirely fruitless exercise in cerebral fitness; nothing more.Math teachers tend to be complete nerds who are great with numbers and terrible at connecting with people.Math teachers are typically inept at associating math lessons with reality.Math is completely unemotional for most people. It doesn't engage you on any personal level. Without any spark of feeling to drive a student's interest, they will never become captivated by the subject.I always managed top grades in math studies and took most of the advanced courses up until college. Honestly it bored me to death, but it was pretty easy for me so I could score well without much effort. The only time I was ever really excited about math is when I was at home, programming my 8086. I got a 486 when I was around 12-13 and started coding 3D transformation algorithms for a simple rendering engine I was building. I had to teach myself the math, and I actually found it pretty intuitive because it fit into a greater purpose; it had context in a project that I was really passionate about completing. It didn't dawn on me how little I actually cared about math for the sake of math until I started taking advanced courses as a freshman in college. The professor sucked. He wrote his own course book and it was almost completely illegible (it didn't help that I hate sloppy handwriting). He was everything you would expect in a stereotypical mathematician: impersonal, disconnected from his students, and obsessed with numbers. Not once did we get out of our seats and put our theories and knowledge to the test in any real life circumstances. Not once did he approach students individually to discover their innate talents or interests. He might has well have been a talking textbook. It was an absolute bore, and it permanently threw a wet blanket on any interest I had in the subject for many years. The sad thing is that I absolutely love physics. If I hadn't pursued a career in computers, it probably would have been physics (or neurology, but I didn't quite discover my passion for the subject until much later in life). Unfortunately physics has extreme demands for mathematical ability. If only I had somehow brought the two together years ago, it probably would have given me some passion for the subject. It seems to me that once you get beyond the basics, math studies really need to have a place in the bigger picture. Teaching advanced concepts & math history without any thought to application is possibly the most effective way to drive students away from the subject.

Math is abstract and the more abstract it gets, the more difficult it gets. What is 1/3? If you visualize a pie, then 1/3 is one out of three slices of pie, all three of which make up the whole pie. What does it mean for a metric space to be compact? You can appeal to your knowledge of Euclidean space and closed sets to help understand the concept of metric spaces and compactness, but there isn't much freedom for relying on real world experience anymore (if you disagree, then substitute compact metric space with something appropriately abstract) and you are instead forced to appeal to previous mathematical knowledge. Math is rigorous. This applies mainly to higher level math and can hinder both mathematical understanding and mathematical doing. If math is presented in a very rigorous manner, it can be difficult to translate this into something more intuitive. Compare the intuitive explanation of a limit to the epsilon-delta definition for a good example of this. Reading proofs can be especially difficult because they not only require you to be able to comprehend mathematical gibberish but to be able to do so continuously while following a mathematical train of thought for several lines, paragraphs, or even pages. Additionally, having to translate the other way can make actually producing rigorous mathematical work (e.g. doing proofs) very difficult. Math can be counter-intuitive which can make it confusing. Any area of math involving infinity gives a good example of this. A good portion of any undergraduate level linear algebra textbook is going to have the disclaimer "for finite vector spaces" somewhere in almost every theorem because the friendly, intuitive theorems of finite dimensional linear algebra fall apart in infinite dimensions. Math has prerequisites. If you don't understand the prerequisites well, then topics that build on them will be very difficult to comprehend. Some people have an easier time with hardcore logic and abstractions than other people. I'd like to think I'm good at math but I am very bad at art and so an equally valid question from my perspective might be "Why is drawing so hard?" Really, I mean I do notice when some people have slightly taller heads than other people or slightly bigger/smaller ears, etc., but how on earth can people look at someone's face and not only be able to comprehend all the details but also be able to translate them into a portrait that looks exactly like that person? How do they even create continuous shading with only one pencil? When I try to do that I can only get 2-3 shades: light, dark, and maybe some sort of in between.

Math is hard because it is important enough to study the hard parts of it. Everything can be difficult or easy depending on how deep you go in. Can you calculate 1+2? Did you get 3? Good. Was that hard? Of course not. If the only math anyone expected you to do was things like 1+2, would you think that math is hard? No. Likewise, if people expected you to run a marathon each day, you would ask why is running so hard. If people expected you to beat chess grandmasters, you'd be asking why is chess so hard. They don't expect this of you. Why? Because it's not important. If you're not a professional athlete, running marathons is not important, you can stay healthy with much milder exercise. Chess is a fun and beneficial hobby but ultimately it's not very important - so society doesn't force you to play chess, you do it if you feel like it. But math is important. The more math you know, the better you'll be equipped to handle a variety of situations in your professional and personal life. Society realizes this and requires that everyone studies math. And not just the easy parts - people are challenged to study a relatively high level of math, because of all its benefits. By definition the math studied will be hard, because if it was easy, people would be required to study even harder math! It's not only the average college student that studies much math. Professional academics advance the frontiers of mathematical research - and here again, because math is so important, a lot of smart people put a lot of effort in it, so the math they come up with is much, much harder than what the average person can handle. I've mentioned the "required" math to be relatively high - it's relative only to the aptitude of the average person, it's a drop in the ocean compared to all the math that is out there. There is another aspect - while society is right about teaching math to everyone, it is often very wrong about which parts of math to teach, and how. Anything can seem hard if it is taught poorly.

There are a number of reasons why people claim that mathematics is difficult: mathematics has a very low tolerance level for errors. In many subjects, you can get by with reasonable approximations of an answer. In mathematics, you usually don't get away with approximations. Your answer has to be exact. I would argue that most subjects are in fact harder than mathematics, but since you can get away with approximations in most fields (which often leads to a lot of B.S.), many people feel that these fields are easier, while they're in fact just getting away with an incorrect or incomplete answer. In mathematics, if you're wrong, you will know it immediately.;people tell each other that mathematics is difficult, which reinforces their view that mathematics is difficult. If you constantly tell yourself and are told by others that mathematics is difficult, then you'll find it difficult, regardless of whether it's actually difficult;many people haven't even mastered very basic concepts before moving on to more difficult ideas in mathematics. You really shouldn't be doing calculus if you aren't even comfortable with basic algebra, yet many people are doing exactly that. You never should move on to a more advanced topic if the foundation on which that topic is built isn't as obvious to you as '1+1=2';mathematics is dense. People, especially in this era, are used to skimming, and they mostly get away with it, since most authors don't refrain from taking up ten pages to explain an idea that you could explain on just one page. In mathematics, it's the complete opposite. You may have a very thin 50-page textbook that has a wealth of information and requires more time and practice than a 500-page textbook in, say, psychology. Yet many people try to get through this very dense textbook in the same way as they would get through a not-so-dense humanities textbook, which is a recipe for disaster. Or they will feel that they are slower and then think that they're doing poorly because it takes so much time, while that's in fact just because the book is dense rather than because of their lack of understanding.mathematics simply requires a lot of practice. If you don't practice, and many people who find mathematics hard don't, then you simply won't get it. Too many students read a mathematics textbook as if it's a novel, and this simply doesn't work. You have to sit down with your textbook on your left side and plenty of empty sheets of paper on your right and just do tons of exercises.

1. Anyone who reads what college students write will quickly realize that many students find writing difficult. 2. In addition, what we call "math" is really three different subjects. 1) Arithmetic. We know what that is. 2) What I call quantitative reasoning, this is the ability to know what answers are ridiculous. 3) Then there's math. Arithmetic is to math as spelling is to creative writing - maybe nice to have, but by no means essential. Most people never learn ANY math.  Math is not about adding and subtracting, or even differentiating and integrating. Math is about the search for structured beauty. It is more akin, in some ways, to sculpture or poetry (especially in highly structured forms) than to engineering. 3. In elementary school, we are usually taught by people who don't like math and who never do any.  If you wanted to take music lessons, you would demand that the teacher know how to play (and probably that he/she listen to music). If you wanted to learn how to cook, dance, write or anything else.... It would be similar. Why is math different? 4. Math is taught all wrong. We teach math (mostly) in one of two ways. I will draw analogies to learning to play the piano. Method 1: At the first lesson, the student taps middle c repeatedly. At the second lesson the d next to the c. And so on for 88 lessons before even starting to learn a song.  Method 2: At the first lesson, the student watches a video of Vladimir Horowitz. At the next lesson, Art Tatum. And so on. The student is not permitted to touch a piano. 5. We teach math as if it were easy, when it is, in fact, hard.  One huge steppingstone for many is negative numbers. Do you know how long it took the smartest mathematicians to learn to deal properly with them? Thousands of years! We teach kids that they are supposed to get the right answer, probably on the first attempt at each problem. Why should they? 6. Culturally, we permit badness at math in ways we do not permit badness at other subjects.  "Oh, I'm no good at math!" is fine to say. "Oh, I never learned to read!" - not so much.  7. Math is formal. It is the most formal subject, and most people have little or no practice dealing with formal subjects.

Alright, this is a topic that’s pretty close to my heart, and I’m gonna have to disagree with most of the other answers for this topic. I would posit that mathematics isn’tnearly as hard as most people think it is. However, it is so heavily stigmatized that people begin to have the wrong ideas when going into math, which only hurts them in the end. So, why is math perceived as such a hard thing? I’ll list the reasons: Bad beginnings – Math is highly foundation-based, and it is something that continues to build upon itself as you go higher up in education. People’s main foundation of mathematical knowledge, which begins at the elementary school level, isn’t as good as it needs to be. Why? Because elementary school teachers often don’t like teaching math.[1] [2] When a teacher doesn’t enjoy what they’re teaching, the student is almost definitely not going to enjoy it, either.Media stigma – Math gets a bad reputation with virtually every reference made to it in the media. When cartoons are constantly perpetuating the idea that math is boring, or math is difficult, or math is something no one wants to do, it’s not difficult to see why children would hate it. Even if they don’t hate it, it will almost definitely make them approach math much more apprehensively, and that is arguably the worst attitude to have when trying to learn something. When’s the last time you went into something thinking, “I don’t know if I’m going to be able to understand this, it seems like it’s going to be difficult,” and came out of it thinking ,“Wow, that concept was easier to grasp than I expected!” It’s really not a common sequence of events.Excuses – If you were to ask how many times a math teacher gets the question, “When am I going to use this in real life?”, you would probably get a ridiculous eye-roll and a long lecture. The thing is, you won’t use most of it in real life. But that’s not exactly a problem. You seldom quote Hamlet or Catcher in the Rye in real life. NFL players aren’t expected to do pushups or lift weights in the middle of the playing field. However, these things are still important to do, because they help us grow in different ways. Mathematics is no different. But people are so eager to use this excuse when they can’t do something the first time, and get discouraged from trying it any further.So, to answer your question, I don’t buy the narrative that mathematics is inherently any more difficult than, say, analyzing sociopolitical structures. You have to realize that there are things you know now that are so ingrained in your brain that they seem like common sense, and you can’t imagine not knowing them. But there was a time when you didn’t know these things. By that logic, what is really outside of the grasp of human comprehension? The things you could be thinking are absolutely impossible to understand now could very well be common sense to you in a year. If you don’t go into something thinking it’s going to be hard, and really internalize the concept that, hey, this is understood by a lot of people, so there’s got to be some sense behind it, you’ll be surprised by what you’re able to learn. Hope that helps! Footnotes [1] Too many teachers can't do math, let alone teach it [2] Elementary teachers’ weak math skills spark mandatory crash courses | Toronto Star Aman Karunakaran's answer to Why is mathematics so hard?

Most people consider math hard, because they have weak foundations in the subject material. Then when they try to do something in math, they struggle with it. That difficulty leads many persons to give up prematurely and accept that they aren’t good at math and that math is hard because our society has developed an acceptability in declaring that math is hard and that we may suck at it. There is a shame associated with not being good at reading or writing, but when it comes to math, we often brag “I suck at math.” and wear that statement proudly. It’s strange. Then there is the reality that math is hard. If I told you to prove numbers existed, could you do it? The idea of numbers is arbitrary and abstract. It’s representative of an idea of value and nothing more. Sure, the word apple is arbitrary in that it is applied to a fruit, but you can at least pick that apple up to build up that association. You really can’t pick up -1 or pi. You have to trust that it is what it is. Once we’ve gotten past that association, we take the numbers away and still teach you it is mathematics. The abstract becomes even more abstract. The only foundation left is pretty much logic and logic doesn’t make intuitive sense to a lot of people, because it follows rigid rules that don’t seem to always make sense. For instance, what’s the difference between or and or? Most people would say they are the same and they would be both right and wrong. That doesn’t seem like it can make sense to people. What about the difference between + and ⊕? They are the same question and yet, one inherently looks harder than the other simply because it’s difficult to sense what the distinction being made is in the former question. Part of that is the abstract nature of mathematics and logic. Part of that is the limitation of the English language for describing logic operations. All of these issues compound to make math less accessible to people who do not have a solid foundation in the why of mathematics. Understanding that why really solidifies the ability to do mathematics, because you can understand when all of these symbols are meant to work together. That’s crucial and is often overlooked when we teach students through rote memorization. I mean, if I told you + means inclusive or, then asked you to solve 1 + 2, what would you tell me the answer is? At least, when tutoring and teaching math, these appeared to be the primary things I noticed causing my students problems.

The problem with math, versus other talents like writing—it requires at least 10-12 years just to grasp until calculus level, and if you fall behind one, two years—with bad teachers-- it may be hard to catch up to that level of math that's needed.  Many people(including me!) had bad experiences of one, two years, of bad teachers, fell behind—and while you're already behind, problems get more and more challenging, then you get frustrated you're behind—and by that time you can't  catch up to the brilliant students there. And get this, till 10th grade, that's considered basic. That's ten years just to grasp basic math.   Unlike writing—other things—that yes, require practice, and hard work—but you don't necessarily need formal training, and constant discipline to first of all, like it, and to secondly, to be good at it. (You can pick up writing, any time—there's no exact set of from addition-->to calculus like math does)  It's quite difficult to effectively teach math, which is the  foundation of so many things, and I found that the k-12 school system severely lacks good teachers that effectively teach math, and as such, very frequently it's required from the parents to be involved and make sure kids do homework and get it. I had a brilliant father at home who taught well, but was too busy, and missed the cue signs when I started getting way worse in math.  Many in the high achieving schools(including my brother), have involved parents who help them after school, take extra classes, etc—because effective teaching of math on average, in the US, does not exist.  It's a terrible problem, and this was written by the way, by a person who hates and sucks at math(<---Me). It's a serious problem the fact that the world is moving only more towards math and data extraction direction, and yet,  teaching math, making it an urgent priority that kids get a basic, good, grasp of math only seriously exists in highly motivated families that the parents make it their business to make sure kids  grasp and get the fundamental skills of math.

Math isn't difficult. The way it's taught is difficult. In math class, you'd be told there are 8 kids and 4 cookies. Your task would be to divide them up equally. The answer would be 1/2 a cookie each. In real life, there would be multiple solutions. Maybe not all kids like ginger cookies. Maybe there would be other snacks. Maybe you wouldn't bring out the cookies because they don't break neatly into halves. That's all mathematical reasoning. In math class, you'd be told apples are 3 for $5. How many apples can you buy for $8? But that's not a realistic problem. In real life, you might decide the oranges are a better deal. Or you'd have $10 to spend on apples for apple bobbing at the church fundraiser. Since your store is normal they sell apples by the pound. So you'd pick out the smallest. Or you'd ask the produce manager if there were some imperfect apples that she might donate to the church then use the $10 on something else. In math class, 90% of the time the numbers have no context so you're just manipulating them for no purpose. The answers won't solve world peace. Whether they're right or wrong they'll end up in the trash. Math is using numbers as an aid in decision making. When making decisions, the context is important. You know why the numbers are what they are. You know also how flexible the situation is. In math class, there is no context. Or the context is made up, unrealistic and inflexible. As an unschooled child, my daughter learned mathematical thinking from the decisions she made. One of the best sources was video games. Just ordinary games like Mario Brothers and Pokemon. She figured out how to use the numbers in the games to make choices. By the time she was 14, she decided to take her father's college statistics course for fun. She did better than 90% of the students who had 12+ years of school math. From that, it seems school math hinders learning math. Since my husband teaches remedial Algebra and pre-Algebra to incoming college students, he'd agree.

First, because it is cumulative. Everything builds on what came before. So, if you fail to learn/understand one piece, then it is almost impossible to make sense of later parts of mathematics that depend on that piece. Second, it is taught poorly, especially in early grades. People who become elementary school teachers often (know that they) don't really understand mathematics, and think it is less important for them to fully understand mathematics. Combining this with the first point, you can see why many people will, at some point, find mathematics to be hard Third, over time, math textbooks get worse. To convince yourself of this, go find a copy of Courant’s 1937 book on calculus. In my opinion, this is the best calculus book ever written. It explains all of the key ideas and illustrates them with real applications. It teaches people how to solve hard problems. The “new math” of the 1960's replaced this approach with an emphasis on abstract theory (possibly inspired by the efforts of Bourbaki to do the same thing to math at the highest level of cutting edge research). This might have been appropriate for the miniscule fraction of people who would go on to become professional mathematicians. But it was a disaster for most students. The over-reaction was to remove most of the theoretical aspects, and replace them with … effectively nothing. This resulted in textbooks without adequate theory and without real applications. Instead, students got (and still get) drill-and-kill based on pattern recognition rather than understanding. And they got obviously artificial problems like “the melting snowman walking past the lamppost” that encouraged students to believe that calculus had nothing useful to offer.

Math is difficult because everything is difficult. Writing stories is difficult. Dancing is difficult.   Acting is difficult.   A few years ago I heard a section on the radio where they brought people in off the street and asked them to read the weather report. They were appalling. Really, really bad. Reading the weather on the radio is difficult. Writing good answers on Quora is difficult.  A very few people are good at any of these. But with most things, it's hard to know just how bad you are. Watch the early American Idols. Most of those people are dross. But they are really, truly horribly disappointed when they are booted off.   I think I could read the weather on the radio, just as well as the person who reads it now. I will probably be shocked when I find out how bad I am at it. Go to any restaurant or cafe in Los Angeles - most of the wait staff moved to LA because they wanted to be actors. They really thought they have a chance of being a famous (or even working) actor.  But most of them don't, because it's really difficult to be a good actor. Your job is probably difficult. I probably couldn't do it. When I tell people what my job is, they start talking to me about it, because they think they have something interesting to tell me about my job. (I'm a psychologist.) But I think I have it bad? I should probably try being Mikka Luster - "You're a cook. I cook in my kitchen. Let me tell you about your job".   But if you're not good at math, you know it. It hits you in the face.  Straight away. Hard.  There's no pretending or fooling yourself. I can throw a steak on a grill, or make a pasta sauce and pretend I know how to cook.*  But I can't, ever, integrate that equation. Obligatory XKCD comic:  *A friend of mine used to like baking cakes. Their friends were polite and said "Yum! Delicious cakes!" The friend thought they knew how to bake. They sold cakes to a place that did 'Farmhouse Teas'. On more than one occasion, a customer returned the cake, because it was inedible.

Learning math is often likened to learning a foreign language. Both subjects involve the building up of basic knowledge before advancing to a higher level of study. Let’s say, when we study trigonometry or calculus for example, we need to have a stable and concrete algebra foundations in order to solve more complex problems. But can we be definitely sure that most students have mastered all their basic concepts before progressing to a higher level of mathematics? First, we should take a look at our current education system. Many schools, which I have studied at or visited to gain experience, etc., adopt a similar education style, particularly when it comes to teaching mathematics. Teachers will run through a set of pre-prepared notes, which consist of many different types of math questions. These examples are done and after the lessons are completed, students will proceed on to do their tutorials. Then, the module is considered finished and here goes the next topic. How can we be sure that students have successful mastered the basic concepts? The truth is that they don’t. How many of your classmates have lamented about their woes of trigonometry? This stems from the way we teach math. Rather than teaching students the reasoning and proof behind formulas and rules, we tend to slant our emphasis on the applications of these formulas. The main reason why many people find mathematics so hard come from the situation of them not fully grasping a concept and then getting lost going forward as the foundation for that string of knowledge is missing. Shifting our focus to the reasoning behind mathematics principles will make students understand the purpose of the formulas. of course, learning something foreign blindly will make it so hard. P.S. I recently read the potato paradox, it is very interesting. Go read more about it! From the Universal Book of Mathematics: Fred brings home 100 pounds of potatoes, which (being purely mathematical potatoes) consist of 99 percent water. He then leaves them outside overnight so that they consist of 98 percent water. What is their new weight? The surprising answer is 50 pounds.

Because it is highly cumulative and mastery is required at every level before advancing on to the next level. More than any other subject, math builds from one section to another. You can’t do multiplication if you don’t have an excellent understanding of addition. You can try, but it will probably eat you alive. Similarly, you can’t do algebra if you don’t understand arithmetic that well. And you won’t be able to do calculus if you’re struggling with algebra. You can’t just get through one level and move onto the next, you have to have full understanding, because at the next level, the previous level will be considered ‘grunt work’, and will be assumed automatic. My college calculus book, for example, went through complicated sections of Algebra, Algebra 2 level concepts at least, in one or two steps in a problem, assuming that it would be no problem for a calculus student to be able to quickly execute this algebra. Unfortunately, this is too often not the case, and students struggle with the basic material that they supposedly mastered. When I was in algebra 2, we were learning about solving 3-D systems (by substitution and elimination, not matrices). For whatever reason, I could not get the problems right. I did so many 3-D systems that semester, looked at worksheets on the internet, went to the extra problems in the back of the book, did anything that would help me get the right answer. By the end of the semester, after many, many hours of extra practice, I might have been getting the right answer half the time. Keep in mind that this was well after our class moved on from the single day we spent learning about 3-D systems, well after I got the 3-D systems on the test wrong, right up until the final exam. My algebra skills improved significantly that semester, and a lot of the improvement came after I started diligently circling my negative signs, because in a lot of cases, I was writing them scrappily and not paying attention to them. Why didn’t I figure this out earlier in math career, rather than spending many, many hours struggling through 3-D systems? Because, for the rest of the algebra that I had learned, it wasn’t that big of a deal. I might not pay attention to the negatives in a couple of problems, and lose a few points on the test because of it. Big deal. But suddenly, when you can’t get any problems right because of it, it is a big deal. I remember another instance in high school, where I was helping a student in intermediate algebra (basically Algebra 1.5, for students who are not ready for Algebra 2). It was April and the student was a senior, one month from graduation. The math problems were 2-D systems, to be solved using elimination. We had a situation where one of the equations had a -2x and other equation had a +2x, obviously to be eliminated so the rest of the system could be solved. I asked him what -2+2 was, and he had no idea. He was trying to do algebra without a basic understanding of negative numbers. And this is what I think happens a lot. Somewhere, a basic principle is missed, or misunderstood. The student is passed through because they know the material ‘well enough’. But then they go on to the next level, and suddenly this small concept that they struggled with a little bit is assumed knowledge in the next level. My Algebra 2 teacher once threatened that if we were made a common mistake on our tests (I don’t remember what the mistake was) he would give us a zero on the test. I’m almost positive he never did it, and I don’t agree with the approach. However, he is right in that small mistakes and misunderstandings like this should not simply be allowed to slip through the system. They should be taken notice of, and corrected as quickly as possible, because down the road, even the small gaps in math can make a difference. Additionally, I think there are some issues in the way some topics are approached. Fractions are pounded in way too much detail in elementary and middle school. In algebra, they are rarely used, and being able to manipulate them is not that important. They are more common in calculus, specifically in integral calculus, but most students have already forgotten everything they learned in middle school by this point, and a calculus student shouldn’t have a problem refreshing themselves on fraction operations. There should be much more emphasis on exponentiation, because that is much more integral to being able to do high school algebra successfully. In other words, emphasis should be placed on the topics most required in the next level, because is that what students will need to be successfully. However, I would say the crux of the problem is not the teaching, but students being passed through without full understanding.

I have studied math throughout my life. I almost became a mathematician, but I quit my PhD program partly because I found math too hard. I switched into philosophy, which is no easier but is hard for different reasons. One reason math can be hard is that something can work without anyone understanding why it works. This cannot happen in philosophy. A reason learning math that others have done can be hard is that when you are learning something new, you often have to take on faith a bunch of definitions and facts that you can’t yet make sense of. Why is the person defining this concept or setting up this construction in exactly this way rather than all of the other ways they could have done it? Often my first reaction to a new piece of math has been revulsion at technical complexities, and learning involved breaking down my natural resistance and going with the flow. Some but not all of this problem can be blamed on suboptimal presentations of new material. A reason doing math yourself can be hard is that it often involves a long series of steps. You can make a mistake along the way that will vitiate everything that follows. Or you can fail to make some inference that would be easy for someone else. This issue can be helped by doing math with other people, but often that is not possible. (Obviously doing math yourself is also hard, relative to learning math that others have done, because you have to think stuff up.) Doing a kind of math depends on intuition that you only get by doing that kind of math (at multiple levels of particularity). Not having that intuition is more blocking than it is for learning other skills. (Being bad at piano doesn’t prevent you from practicing.) Learning math is like solving an endless complex of chicken-and-egg problems. At lower levels of math education, often the explanations provided to students are incoherent, and the things they are being taught could never have been discovered by the greatest genius in the way and order they are taught. Students may even come up with alternative but equally valid ways of thinking about problems and be told that they are wrong. At least telling students they are wrong when they are clever and right often does not harm them.

Let me suggest you first read this essay called “Lockharts Lament”… https://www.maa.org/external_archive/devlin/LockhartsLament.pdf Simplified, the essay points out that if we applied how we teach math to music, then students would spend 12 grades learning music notation, recognizing and reading music, reading gaps, chords, arpeggio’s, etc… And we’d leave actually playing music until college - as an advanced endeavor. There is tremendous truth in this analogy. Mathematics education is focused on the least important and least useful parts of mathematics - all designed around a requirement for pretty advanced symbolical Alegebra in order to graduate high school. However, very few people (less than 1%) use algebra extensively in college OR in their careers - it simply isn’t that critical. If, instead, we focused education on practical math - math that made sense in terms of our lives - then I don’t believe people would find math nearly as difficult. For example, my son on the autism spectrum struggles badly with math - even simple addition. But, put him in a store wanting to buy two things and then ask him what they cost together? His math is hundreds of times better and his mind far faster - because that MEANS something. For a second reading recommendation: The Math Myth | The New Press by Andrew Hacker. Or his NYTimes OpEd piece Is Algebra Necessary? . NOTE: I answer this as a mathematician (MS- Applied Math, UC-San Diego, worked on rockets and the Space Shuttle) who is also a father of 2, an advertising executive with highly measured advertising, and have taught in business schools.

Few reasons why Mathematics is so hard can be: Exposure - Mathematical skills aren’t usually given a lot of attention outside of the classroom. As one quote I saw many years ago said, "We play with what we love". Play with numbers, patterns and words from the very beginning and many learning problems will never develop. Logical Skills-Maths requires logic, and many kids are not trained on logical skills at an early age. It helps to decide which problem-solving skill to try first. Support-Children need regular support in order to recognize the mathematics in the world around them, and parents are often the best people to provide this support. Many children don’t receive support or guidance to finish Maths homework. It makes learning tougher for them. Maths Basics – Basics about Mathematics need to be developed among students from elementary level. Maths is highly foundation-based, and it is something that continues to build upon itself as you go higher up in education. Weak basics make students feel Maths as a hard subject. Tips to develop better Mathematical skills: 1.Maths Foundation – Calculations become easier if your child understands the Mathematical concepts. Rather than just doing drills or memorizing rules, help them visualize what’s taking place. Practice can help children master the facts and solve problems faster, so use Maths games, flash cards, join Maths Foundation classes to help them learn. 2.Treat Maths as a Game – Too many of us think of Maths as work, something we do because we have to. If instead we were taught to think of it as a game, we’d probably look at it differently. Maths games can help them learn Mathematical skills while at play. 3. Make Mathematics Real – Let your child see how important Maths is in life while paying bills, cooking, or making a grocery list. Practical, real-life applications of basic Mathematical concepts can help them learn faster, so take them shopping with you, let them help with measuring ingredients, setting the table, counting fruit and vegetables in the refrigerator, etc. 4.Do Maths Every Day – Make sure that your child spends time doing calculations every single day. Spend at least 10 minutes with quick Maths activities such as counting, adding, subtracting, multiplying and dividing, or give them problems to solve on their own. Sit with them while they work on puzzles or assignments. 5.Try New Techniques – Don’t repeat the same activities over and over till your child gets bored with them. Instead, switch it up to keep things interesting. Try Maths-based story books, videos or educational shows on TV, party games that involve Maths challenges, and more. 6. Abacus and Brain Gym-Learning Abacus can help your child improve his Mathematical skills, calculations speed, concentration etc. Doing brain gym exercises regularly will develop left and right brains. 7.Competition and Rewards – Your child will be more interested in Maths if they feel a sense of achievement when they master certain concepts or skills. Reward them when they solve problems or find solutions on their own, especially when they do calculations in their head. Along with other students, set up group quizzes or competitions with rewards for the winners.

At school, they merely do this: (a+b)(a+b)(a+b)(a+b)(a+b)(a+b) Then: a(a+b)(a+b)+b(a+b)(a+b)a(a+b)(a+b)+b(a+b)(a+b) Then: a(a2+2ab+b2)+b(a2+2ab+b2)a(a2+2ab+b2)+b(a2+2ab+b2) Then: a3+2a2b+ab2+a2b+2ab2+b3a3+2a2b+ab2+a2b+2ab2+b3 Combining similar things: a3+3a2b+3ab2+b3a3+3a2b+3ab2+b3  But what is the right way? The right way is to ask, what does it mean? What is the pattern here? Not only do we need to see the pattern, but also one step before and after it: Here is the pattern:(illustration credit) [1] which is the “why” part.  Here is how to think about the pattern, the “what is going on” part. I will keep the examples in this part within the power of 2 or (a+b)2(a+b)2 , to keep the topic accessible to all readers: A kind grandma has many grandchildren and loves to give candies to those grandchildren of hers who visit her. She gives even more candies if more children visit her together, like so: if a child went there alone, he’d get aa candy, whereas if he went there with another child, they’d both get a2a2. So on Monday, aa girls went there together, and together they got a2a2 candies. After the girls left, bb boys went there together and got b2b2 candies from the friendly grandma. The total candies for that day, when boys visited separately from girls was a2+b2a2+b2. Then they realized they could get even more candies if they all went there together. So when the boys and girls went there at the same time, each of the a+ba+b children got a+ba+b more candies and all the children got a total of (a+b)2(a+b)2 candies. That is, each of the bb boys got aa more candies (because of aa girls), and each of the aa girls got bb more candies( because of bb boys). Thus the boys got baba more candies than before, and the girls got abab candies more than before: ba+ab=2abba+ab=2ab. So (a+b)2(a+b)2 is 2ab2ab more than a2+b2.a2+b2. Although simple, this is a powerful way of thinking. Suppose I ask you to solve 992992 without paper and pen. How would you do it now that you know grandma’s story? We factor them apart: (90+9)2=902+2∗90∗9+92=8100+2∗810+81=(90+9)2=902+2∗90∗9+92=8100+2∗810+81= 8100+(810+40)+(810+41)=8100+1701=9801.8100+(810+40)+(810+41)=8100+1701=9801. Now try solving 99829982 without paper and pen (it is easier than you think! For solution, please see Appendix A at the far end of this answer). And the fun does not stop there. We can use (a+b)2(a+b)2 as a shortcut for multiplication. Suppose I asked you to take two integers which differ by 22: say 55 and 33. Multiply them: 5∗3=155∗3=15 Add 11 to their product = 15+1=1615+1=16 A perfect square! (a perfect square is the square of an integer, here 42=1642=16). And of course, we can prove this for any nn: The smaller number is nn. Then the other number must be n+2n+2. Their product: n(n+2)=n2+2nn(n+2)=n2+2n Adding 11 to it: n2+2n+1n2+2n+1 Since 12=112=1 then we get: n2+2n+12n2+2n+12. This is equal to (n+1)2(n+1)2 which is the same structure as our earlier (a+b)2(a+b)2. Cool right? The excellent n2+2n+12n2+2n+12 is interlinked to yet another idea, the arithmetic progression (an arithmetic progression is a sequence of numbers where the difference between one number and the next is a constant.) Take the most common sequence 1,2,3,4….n1,2,3,4….n and square them: 1,4,9,16….n21,4,9,16….n2 Now write the difference of the squared numbers under them: 1,4,9,16,25,36,491,4,9,16,25,36,49 3,5,7,9,11,133,5,7,9,11,13 The second row of numbers is an arithmetic progression where the numbers vary by a constant of 2. (Note that 1,2,3,4….n1,2,3,4….n is also an arithmetic progression, increasing by a constant of 1). But why does the second arithmetic progression differ by 22? Because the consecutive numbers (in 1,2,3,4….n1,2,3,4….n) where each nn becomes n+1n+1 has this square: (n+1)2(n+1)2 which is expanded as: n2+2n+12.n2+2n+12. Now let’s break it up into several pieces; the first piece is n2n2 which is the same idea as taking 1,2,3,4….n1,2,3,4….nand turning it into 1,4,9,16,25,36,491,4,9,16,25,36,49. Consider now that sequence of the difference of the squares—our second arithmetic progression: 3,5,7,9,11,133,5,7,9,11,13--differs by exactly2n+122n+12 or 2n+1.2n+1. This is saying when you add 11 to nn (as with 1,2,3,4…n)1,2,3,4…n), the square of this sequence grows by 2n+12n+1: that is,11 becomes 2∗1+1=32∗1+1=3, 22 becomes 2∗2+1=52∗2+1=5, 33 becomes 2∗3+1=72∗3+1=7, and so on. Drop the 55, and you get a 44. Let’s call 44, nn. Now do n+1:4+1=5n+1:4+1=5. With me so far? Good. Now multiply nnto n+1n+1, just like we did earlier: n(n+1)n(n+1). In our case here: 4∗5=204∗5=20. Now, to the end of 2020, concatenate a 22 and the earlier-dropped55 back to it. (recall that the 22 that you concatenated and the +1+1 that you added to nn in this example are linked because of what happens to n+1n+1, when nn becomes n2n2): 20252025 Let’s try this again with 852852. Calculator says: 72257225. Our method says: 8+1=98+1=9, then 8∗9=728∗9=72, then concat the 22 and the 55: 72257225. Neat! The excellent (a+b)2(a+b)2 still has more wonders to amaze you with. Suppose you want to solve a slightly tedious problem like this: (a2−2ab+b2)∗(a2+2ab+b2)(a2−2ab+b2)∗(a2+2ab+b2) Since we know the backstory and how (a+b)2(a+b)2 expands, we can use it as a short-cut to solve this: (a−b)2∗(a+b)2(a−b)2∗(a+b)2 The two terms have an exponential in common, so we recast them as: ((a−b)∗(a+b))2((a−b)∗(a+b))2 Multiply a to a and b to b, without changing the external exponent: ((a2−b2))2((a2−b2))2 That is, (a+b)∗(a−b)=a2−ab+ba−b2(a+b)∗(a−b)=a2−ab+ba−b2 and −ab−ab cancels baba, so all that is left is a2−b2.a2−b2. Now ((a2−b2))2((a2−b2))2 is merely the same thing as (a+b)2(a+b)2, only now aa and bb have been raised to the power of 22 and the sign has reversed. Thus, we expand like we did with (a+b)2:(a+b)2: a4−2a2b2+b4a4−2a2b2+b4 For this next part, let’s jump up one step and try examples with the powers of 3. I am also going to use the wonderful Julia programming language (you can treat it as a calculator) to demonstrate a new link to the Binomial Triangle, aka Pascal’s Triangle, even though it was discovered several times before Pascal. If you are new to programming and Julia, you could either just look at the results, or spend 30 minutes on my other answer which contains just the right amount of Julia and programming to understand what is going on here; in any case, the explanation is intuitive: # importing a special package in Julia  using DSP Now we can use convolution (I’ll explain soon): # define a base to start from baze = [1];          # define a kernel that is to be convoluted kernel = [1 1];     # repeat one time: baze = conv(baze, kernel)  # result >  1  1 Now let’s see what that was all about: an ordered list of numbers is called a vector. I will briefly discuss about some particular groups of people and their reasons to find mathematics difficult. Each group can have different reasons.  Most of what follows is based on personal experience and what I have read in different articles. Of course, in an answer like this there will be many generalisations: Mathematicians (or theoretical computer scientists) find it difficult because there are several easily stated but extremely difficult problems in maths which may take months/years/centuries to solve. And also because there are things like Inter-universal Teichmüller theory developed by fellow mathematician(s) which many professional mathematicians would not be able to understand. PhD students in mathematics find it difficult because they are going through a very difficult process of building a particular area of specialisation and learning how to generate new mathematics in that area. They face failure again and again before something good comes out in the narrowly focussed field they are working on.  Sometimes, even after 4-7 years of school nothing "good" comes out of it.  Other students in mathematics/theoretical computer science/physics find it difficult because, well some of the stuff in abstract maths is quite difficult! It takes time to get used to things like Topology and Category theory but many students are not fortunate enough to have good teachers guiding them well through the process of learning these things. They have to grasp the basics of a wide spectrum of areas in mathematics which can be a difficult task.  Students and professionals in other fields that use mathematics as a tool find it difficult because they may have some idea about the abstractness of mathematics but they haven't been exposed to it properly to be able to work out all the proofs of things that they are using (many wouldn't even see the necessity of proving that those tools work). If they are good at using the particular tools then they may not even find "mathematics" difficult.   Others (discussed in detail in some of the answers here) usually find it difficult because of the  difficult school experience they had in something which was disguised as mathematics but which was mostly just algebraic manipulations. You had to learn and practice certain algorithms (example: how to find an integral) on which you were graded. There were absolute markers set by the system which would tell you if you were good at "maths" or not. And due to some reasons like low IQ and lack of early childhood training, many would not do well in those things.  I believe most of them would not find maths difficult for those particular reasons if they were taught maths properly.

There is kind of a vicious circle about math, In my opinion. First for every human being there exists a point at which they stop understanding at least some part of mathematics. Even the most brilliant mathematician can't know the entire field, because the field has become too large like a tree with infinite branches each with infinite numbers of twigs.  Unfortunately, many of the people who choose to teach elementary school run into the point where they stop understanding mathematics a bit too early. This is often because the people who taught them mathematics in elementary school also had a less than complete understanding of what they were teaching. So many of our elementary school teachers then turn around and teach mathematics the way they were taught, through repetition and memorization of procedures. It's very hard to memorize math, but if it's taught well it should make sense. Some kids are able to see the patterns in mathematics and build a strong understanding, in spite of the quality of instruction. But most of those kids, if they stay with mathematics, tend to choose a more lucrative profession than teaching. If they do teach it's usually at the university level, where they teach highly motivated students like themselves. This leaves the less motivated students who have already bumped up against limit of their understanding in math to become elementary school teachers, where they are more likely make math difficult to understand. There are many many exceptions to this pattern, but I think it does explain why many kids find math difficult to learn - it's not inherently difficult if it's taught in a developmentally appropriate way by teachers who understand and like it.

I think I can answer this question because I myself found Mathematics to be a tough subject at one point of time. I was good in Mathematics upto 5th grade, when Math was all about addition, subtraction, division and multiplication. I was a little slow but still I managed to get above average marks. Suddenly after 6th grade, my performance started deteriorating. I was flooded with so many concepts: basic algebra, geometry etc. and by the time I had reached the end of 8th grade, I had gotten 36/100 in my annual exams, which was the worst Math performance of my life. I couldn't understand what had gone wrong in the past three years. In fact, I had studied more in the 8th grade than I had in 7th grade but still the performance kept going down. My father thought this was a serious issue, so he got me a personal math tuitor at home. The teacher used to come to my house at a particular time slot and used to teach me alone daily for 1 hour. The tuitor realised in the first week itself that my basics were really messed up. He first focussed on getting my basics right i.e. the concepts that were taught in 6th grade, then gradually when I had understood those, he switched to concepts that were taught in the 7th grade and eventually we caught up with the 9th grade questions. My whole summer vacations plus an extra month were spent in catching up with the concepts of previous classes. It was then that I realised why I couldn't do better in Math earlier. In 8th grade, I had assumed that even if I don't understand concepts of 6th and 7th grade, I will be able to master class 8th Math just by studying hard. But what makes Math tough is that it is a purely heirarchical subject. When I was in 6th class, I hadn't understood 20–30 % of Math but I moved on to 7th grade without understanding that part. The same happened in 7th grade and that 30% gap moved up to 50% and the missing gaps kept piling up until 8th grade when I found the subject gibberish. No matter how hard I tried, I just couldn't understand the topics. I couldn't even understand the solutions properly. It took a lot of patience and hard work both from my tuitor and myself to finally fill those gaps that I had left in the previous classes. I finally started improving. In fact, once I had started understanding the concepts, Math became an addiction. The subject which I feared the most, became my favorite. I scored 73/80 in my annual exam in 9th grade and scored 80/80 in pre-board exams in 10th grade. Since then, Math has been my favorite subject.
