Let's agree to accept the premise that most people's entire exposure to mathematics occurs in school. Now, if you consider something a "school subject," you'll generally judge your ability at it by the grades you got and the amount of effort you had to put in to achieve them.  Saying "I'm bad at history," most of the time, means "I can't memorize lists of dates" rather than "I can't synthesize information about the chain of events leading up to an outcome and then abstract a general principle from the evidence."   So let's look at where those grades come from. When grading a math assignment, we generally examine whether a student solved the problem correctly, or at least made good progress towards solving the problem.  If so, the student receives credit; if not, well, there's not much way to award points. Imagine what would happen if essays were graded this way.  "Did you do a reasonable job of advancing the argument you made, so that a reader would have a good reason to agree with you?  No?  Well, then, I guess you got that essay wrong.  Can't really give you any points for just writing a bunch of words.  Sorry." But of course that's not how essays are graded.  The essay grading process is something more like this:  Are there as many words here as I asked for?Are they actual words which form actual sentences, according to established rules of spelling and grammar?Does the essay appear to be related to the prompt in some way?And the reason essays are graded this way is that, if they were graded on the basis of whether the student had actually done a good job of writing an essay, then we'd see 30% of students failing Freshman Composition and Intro to Western History and so forth, and the number of people graduating high school and college would drop precipitously. As it stands, the 30% of people who fail Freshman Calculus find mathematics unapproachable, whereas the 30% of people who by all rights ought to have failed Freshman Anthropology merely find that subject dull. And that is why many people find mathematics difficult. --- Postscript: Throughout my entire time in school the only other courses I saw evaluated in such an honest way were the ones for the various athletic teams.  In fact, they were a bit more extreme: you couldn't even enroll in those classes if you weren't good enough to pass their entrance exams.  (If I recall correctly, I think that by the time I was about eleven years old I had already been permanently rejected from all of them.)  That's probably one reason you'll actually hear people admit they're bad at sports, when they'd be loathe to admit being bad at almost anything else.  Except, of course, for math.

James Gay's answer is very good, i just want to combine it with User-10267358060907795720's answer and add a bit of explanation. I personally hated math and found it incredibly difficult for years- all the way through Calc 2 courses in an undergraduate degree. I just figured I wasn't a math person- something i'd known for a long time and just dealt with. But in the last few years I've begun teaching myself some particular mathematics in order to express ideas which, i feel, are worth making precise. I've discovered that I don't find maths difficult- i found how maths are taught impossible, and could only rarely ignore the lesson plans well enough to learn the math.  Being in a school class with timeframes and pressures makes it very difficult to take the time to play with a math concept until you understand what it means and how the parts work together- unless you're ahead of your class level, in which case it's ridiculously easy to do the lesson plans and you can spend your spare time getting even farther ahead. Once you know the math, the lessons are easy-but without personally understanding the underlying processes taken for granted by whomever made the lesson plan, the exercises are often incomprehensible. Why is this? I can't answer definitively, but i think that the famous article Lockhart's Lament [1] (which is definitely worth a read for anyone interested in this question) has some excellent metaphors. Here is what painting would look like if it had gone through the same process that led to mathematics education.  I was surprised to find myself in a regular school classroom— no easels, no tubes of paint. “Oh we don’t actually apply paint until high school,” I was told by the students. “In seventh grade we mostly study colors and applicators.” They showed me a worksheet. On one side were swatches of color with blank spaces next to them. They were told to write in the names. “I like painting,” one of them remarked, “they tell me what to do and I do it. It’s easy!” After class I spoke with the teacher. “So your students don’t actually do any painting?” I asked. “Well, next year they take Pre-Paint-by-Numbers. That prepares them for the main Paint-by-Numbers sequence in high school. So they’ll get to use what they’ve learned here and apply it to real-life painting situations— dipping the brush into paint, wiping it off, stuff like that.Of course we track our students by ability. The really excellent painters— the ones who know their colors and brushes backwards and forwards— they get to the actual painting a little sooner, and some of them even take the Advanced Placement classes for college credit. But mostly we’re just trying to give these kids a good foundation in what painting is all about, so when they get out there in the real world and paint their kitchen they don’t make a total mess of it.  The point here is that painting is an art, and that reducing it to its tiny component steps and then to paint-by-numbers changes it from a fundamentally creative activity to a fundamentally bureaucratic activity. Math, he argues, is also a fundamentally creative art, and has undergone this process. The math taught in schools is so difficult for students because it is a mind-numbing exercise in memorization and application of rote knowledge, instead of the creative activity which practicing mathematicians use on a daily basis and which was used to create the math techniques taught in school. [1] http://www.maa.org/devlin/lockhartslament.pdf

First things first, even mathematicians think math is hard. Don’t let them tell you otherwise. Math is a problem solving endeavor and you will encounter obstacles. These obstacles can be frustrating, but it is important to push through them. Mathematics is hard for several reasons. The first reason is that there is a lot of vocabulary to learn. Some words in math can have definitions that contains several paragraphs or more worth of information encoded in them. When in math someone uses a definition dense word it is to save time and thinking space. Another problem is that math often requires you to be logical and imaginative at the same time. If you don’t understand the concept of symbolism then that will make math even harder. Some people when they first start learning algebra will say, “Math has letters now? I thought math was about numbers.”. The idea of symbolism is at play here. Those letters can “represent” numbers. You could also use pictures as variables though, but that takes more time and energy. Symbolism is a hard concept for many people to grasp. If you struggle with it, then don’t feel bad. Lots of people find symbolism hard to grasp, especially when it goes beyond the realm of textbook literary symbolism. One thing that could be done to help students who struggle with math would be for schools to offer a mathematical terminology class. I know many people with think that this is silly, but I am serious. Many colleges will medical terminology classes because of the amount of vocabulary used in medicine. I think that people, especially those majoring in a STEM field could potentially benefit from such a class. After all, how are you supposed to solve a math problem when you don’t know what the words mean. If I asked you a question about idempotents in a ring and you didn’t know what idempotents were, you would likely have a difficult time solving the problem. As far as the symbolism part goes, I have no idea as to how to help people feel more comfortable with that idea as it pertains to mathematical concepts. If anyone has any ideas on that one, please feel free to let me know. Another reason why math is difficult is because solving any kind of high level problem often requires a certain level of background knowledge as well as experience with that kind of problem That is why when even the best mathematician encounter a problem, the likes of which they have never seen, it is normal to struggle and to feel intimidated by it. I have been there and I have done that. Generally speaking though, math is hard because it requires a lot of mental resources.

Sure, a third grader learning arithmetic (or whatever age that is...) doesn't have the experience and means to apply it outside their classroom. But even when you first learn calculus, there seems to be such a focus on plugging and chugging that WHY you want to learn this in the first place is lost. Yes. Anyone who says maths is easy likely has not had enough mathematics to justify their answer. I went to high school with a friend, let's call him Bill. Bill was above average at high school mathematics, and thought he could pursue a Physics major like me. Bill was terrible at Calculus and ended up dropping out of college. What's the lesson here? Being good at very basic maths doesn't mean you can say maths is easy. That's the equivalent of playing “Twinkle twinkle, little star” on piano and saying that piano is easy. Mathematics is a very complex and beautiful world of sets of relationships between objects. When you're in grade school all the way through your first/second year of college, you're barely scraping what maths is. You're only studying relationships between functions and numbers, nothing more. No one in the world understand all of maths, and no one ever will. By those standards, it is far from easy. 2+1 is easy. Evaluating a line integral is easy, still. Using Galois Theory to solve problems? Considerably harder. Anything is “easy” once you understand it fully, but very few people understand what they're doing in the universe of mathematics, and it requires several years of advanced study to even get a grasp of what's really going on.

Imagine a tree.  Look at the very top, you’ll see the freshest, greenest leaves. The outsides of the branches laced with the new bushes blushing out from within them. That’s new life forming. That’s new life forming from existing life. Trees grown over thousands of years, yielding new greenery from within what already exists. The lower you get along the spine of the tree the less sunlight some of these bushes and branches get. They’re covered in other bushes growing out on top of them. They’re hidden. They’re equally important, of course. They gave life to the newer things.The sunlight doesn’t touch the old ones anymore. Their day in the sun is traded for new growth. Thousands of years, the trunk pulsating nutrients into its million arms. Lengthening itself freely over a plane that spans an infinite space. Heightening itself to no limits. Growing. Widening. Heightening. At the bottom, you would see roots. These roots are covered. Thousands of years of rocks and tiny material has compacted to form dirt and sand. The roots are essential. Our eyes can’t see it. The nitrogen, phosphorous, and potassium that the tree needs it feeds through these roots. Water pumps into the tree from underneath. It survives out of something of a miracle. The ecosystem that has grown this gigantic tree is completely invisible to our eyes. Mathematics is much like a gargantuan tree. Not only is it so massive it gives you a headache, but the roots are so securely fastened into the ground that you didn’t notice at what point the trunk of the tree went underground to form roots. Thousands of years of people developing logic and forming arguments. Some might think we have always been doing that throughout time. Mathematics, however, is different. Its reasoning is more than logic incarnate. It is infallible. When something in mathematics is proven, it is proven forever. The result of the math we have woven, we can see. The technology you hold in your hands was built on the edifice of mathematical rules and thoughts. The technology we interact with on a daily basis uses encryption developed in the last one hundred years. Think about the things that require mathematics to be 100% correct always: BiologyPhysicsChemistryPsychologyTechnologyElectronicsThe complete list is far too long. The difficulty of mathematics yields the integrity and reliability of the things we interact with today. We know that underneath the systems we see we have a highly complex system of rules and parameters that makes them. We have systems within systems within systems. The lower we get—closer to the ground—the easier it gets to lose track of what was actually being understood. Imagine mathematics being 1,000 of these large trees being grown at the same time in the place of one tree. They are connected within one another underground. A whole ecosystem of beauty exists underneath it all. At the roots. But a thousand trees and thousands of years of growth often leaves us with little time to actually grasp complexity. Some of us are lucky to grasp some of its beauty. To maybe follow even one of those roots.

Everything is difficult if you’re doing it right. Math is difficult for many people because it requires a way of logical and abstract reasoning that doesn’t mesh with the way people’s brains naturally operate. We are pre-programmed by evolution to be good at breaking things open with rocks and recognizing scary predators, not calculating Fourier transforms. So we recognize math as being difficult. What would we classify as easy? Cooking? Literature? Biology? If you’d say any of those things, I’d argue that you just stopped learning about them before the going got tough. I’m a physics grad student, not a mathematician - there are many areas of math with which I’m completely unfamiliar, and even the ones which I use on a daily basis can be difficult for me. I don’t understand high level mathematics like some of the fantastic Quora writers here. But I also don’t understand cooking like Jacques Pépin. There are a near-infinity of things that he knows that I don’t, and many many things that he does that I can’t do - high-level cooking is impossibly hard, just like high-level anything. If your goal is to learn just enough to make a living, then math is among the more difficult disciplines, for sure. But if you are passionate about something - for real - and want to take it as far as you can, then before long you’ll be beating your head against the desk(/cutting board/bookshelf/lab table) just like the rest of us. May we all find something that we love so much ;)

To paraphrase the alleged dying words of Edmund Kean, the great 19th century Shakespearean actor, "Math is easy. Comedy is hard." (He actually said "dying" rather than "math.") I think that's relevant in the sense that you can generally find something that for you and perhaps many others is harder than something most people fear.  Some of the other answers here exhibit an example of something that is difficult for many people: clear written communication. As someone who has a master's degree in literature and another in mathematics education, I find writing relatively effortless, while abstract mathematics is constantly ramping up the abstraction and difficulty level, relative to my "talents" (I should add that I'm 65 and any mathematics I pursue at this point is strictly for my own interest. There's no outside, professional pressure on me to know more than I've already mastered as a math teacher, teacher-educator, and teacher-coach).  Some of the better answers make clear that there are many factors that make mathematics challenging (probably a better word than "hard"), and how those factors become increasingly problematic for students - including professionals - as they try to move up the mathematical "tree" and further out onto smaller and smaller branches and twigs. As Einstein said, "Do not worry about your difficulties in Mathematics. I can assure you mine are still greater.”  While some people see that as arrogant and self-important, I believe Einstein meant, among other things, that the more math you learn, the more you realize how much more this is to learn, and even the best will discover places where they struggle mightily to understand.  There's a mathematician at the University of Michigan named Andreas Blass who is rumored to be able to walk into anyone's mathematics lecture and make meaningful contributions, no matter how advanced or esoteric (or far afield from Blass' own areas of research). If this isn't apocryphal, I'd say that makes him the exception, rather than the rule. I think most people, even top-notch mathematicians, are bound to find areas of ignorance and difficulty if they keep exploring the expanding mathematical universe.

Why Is Math So Hard? There are two causes that may be leading to students lack of interest. The first one is purely genetic. We’ve all heard about students who are left brain or right brain; right brain people are creative and artsy while left brainers tend to be more analytical. Which side of your brain is more dominant can certainly contribute to your feelings regarding math, but a new study has shown that there might be something even deeper impacting a student’s mathematical output. Basically, all animals are born with the ability to differentiate between numbers. An infant, for example, can tell the difference between one to two toys. As we grow up, however, our brain should be able to differentiate between larger ratios. A grown human being can easily tell the difference between 11 objects versus 12, a child would not.  some students have deficits in this area, and when we add in symbols for these numbers, or later integers, this deficit worsens. In other words, students have a difficult time processing the numerical worth of the information in front of them. Math Is Cumulative The second issue is usually tacked onto the first one. Math is a cumulative subject – more so than any of the other core content areas. If you don’t learn the fundamentals of fractions, then it’s highly unlikely that you will be able to fully grasp algebra or calculus later on. If a student becomes discouraged at an early age and it is not remediated quickly, then it is probably that the student will become disillusioned with the subject entirely. So, what can we do? The first thing is to remediate. For students who may have a numerical deficit, it is going to take them more time to learn the content and grasp ideas than many of their peers. It is important that if you notice your child is falling behind to get help as soon as possible. Bring it to the teacher’s attention and consider hiring a private tutor to work with your student. Many students become disenchanted with math around the time they take Algebra I. This is a great time to purchase a middle school level curriculum (or pre-algebra) workbook and either work with your student individually or have him or her work with a tutor.

Mathematics is hard because it requires exact thinking, and you start out in life with unruly imaginative thinking that fights hard not to be tamed, think comic books. But you eventually have to let go of childhood thinking and grow up because you are inheriting the world. If you know a mathematical fact, you really know something that is eternal and will still be true long after humanity is extinct. It’s the closest one can get to eternity. Not really :) It’s the study of abstract structures, and after one gets through the classic structures it soon becomes an endless and tedious waste of time. The subject has grown so huge that nobody can hope to keep track of it all anymore, even the titles and abstracts of all the new papers being published, and what’s worse, there’s surely a ton of duplication going on, but nobody can get on top of the field and unify it. Still, to a certain point it teaches mental discipline, which can carry over into many other fields. Today, mastering calculus inducts one into the ranks of the engineers, because that’s their language. Everybody needs to know algebra and trigonometry to be considered educated or even to attend college. Boolean algebra would also be nice in the computer age, along with computer programming theory and algorithms. There’s a sad trend for physicists to try to hijack every new area of math for their physical theories whether it’s real physics or just mental masturbation, look at string theory. Math is going to fill all the available space one day, so get used to it. It’s a good life strategy to learn math through calculus and computer algorithms in one’s youth (before age 25, when the mind changes) to equip the mind for life’s challenges. TLW's Mathematicianscope™, by T.L. Winslow (TLW), "The Historyscoper"™

A2A, thanks. I assume we can exclude bad instruction from consideration and focus on the aspects inherent to mathematics. If so, I believe that that what makes mathematics look and feel hard are two things: (1) that it requires us to overcome several of the strong cognitive biases (List of cognitive biases - Wikipedia) that we are wired to have, and (2) that the results regarded as highest-quality are those where we have achieved a full classiciation of the types of objects at hand. An example of each: (1) Trouble with the universal quantifier (“for every”). For instance, by definition, a sequence is said to converge to a number L if every neighborhood of L contains some tail of that sequence. On reading this definition, we try to imagine ourselves checking *every* neighborhood of L for this condition. (I am not an expert on this, but it seems like we are trying to use a familiar procedure—checking one interval at a time—and this might be a manifestation of the Law of the instrument - Wikipedia ?). But, of course, there are infinitely many neighborhoods of L, so our “visceral” part of the mind gets stressed: How are we going to check them all? (2) Here the hardship is knowing whether we have really found all instances of an object of a specific type. (E.g., find all groups of order 24, or all functions of bounded variation on the interval [0, 1], or all linear transformations that preserve a certain subspace of the vector space). This hardship never goes away: there are still open classification problems. In summary: dealing with infinite (or finite, but intractably large) collections of objects and verifying that a sought list is truly complete. P.S. One might also feel that, in mathematics, the questions that come up in “daily life”, on being stated mathematically, completely change their appearance and don’t even look like anything practical any more. And the answers, accordingly, also don’t look like they answer the original question. But, this afflicts only the novice who is not yet familiar with the mathematical machinery, so it is not a persistent difficulty: eventually, an engineering student gets used to the fact that the mathematics governing the workings of a car is a bunch of equations and experimental values.:) What I have tried to describe are the difficulties that never really go away, as they go against our cognitive wiring. This is just my opinion, so others may disagree.

If you are given an assignment in English, you can in theory write whatever you like, as long as you adhere (to a degree) to the guidelines of the genres you are told to write within, and manage to justify how what you write is correct. There are thousands of ways to write it out, where fluency, vocabulary, and subject-related content (however weakly related it may be) all plays the role in whether the result is correct or not. Two people can essentially write the same, but be several grades apart because they didn’t manage a similar level of argumentation. Mathematics, on the other hand, works on rules. It doesn’t matter how well figured out your mathematical work looks, if the answer, of which there are often just one, is wrong. If two people write the same thing, provided the formulas used, and the answers given are the same, it doesn’t matter how poorly formulated the end statement is, because your equation is correct. As another says, math is easy (or at least doable) if you have the right foundation.  But what is that foundation and how do you get it? The foundation is essentially linguistic.  Algebra is a language with rules, grammar, etc.  The grammar is more critical than in spoken languages, because the power of it is in the manipulations that can be done, relying on that grammar.  There are other aspects to math, but in real life, school-level algebra is the foundation.  And a language is learned by practice. We practice language because we need it.  Kids hear language from their parents and have lessons in school.  But at a young age kids have to learn arithmetic before they are even ready to learn algebra.  So the kids who are able to "get" arithmetic fastest can start earlier.  Then they have to want to practice it and seek opportunities to use it and think about it.  After a few years of this, the language starts to become easy and one can say the student has the beginning of "foundations". The people who go on to specialize in math and show up to answer questions like this one did all this at a stage of childhood they barely remember any more.  They were fortunate to have adequate education, and they are probably more talented in this sort of thing so they got through it faster and were "accelerated", in "honors", etc.   (Some of us are reminded by having children of our own, that we weren't born knowing basic algebra.)  They talk about the process of building on that foundation, and indeed it is not too hard and is very rewarding.  But the people who think math is hard are the ones without that foundation.

Illiteracy and its costs to individuals and to society has long been a focus of concern in public policy. A corresponding lack of ability in mathematics–innumeracy–has received increasing attention in the last few decades. The ability to use basic math is more and more important as modern day society grows more complex. Some children have a problem in learning to read that is disproportionate to any other academic challenge they face. Some children have a corresponding problem with math. For some reason, the ideas just don’t come together for these students. In a recent article in “Current Directions in Psychological Science,” David Geary (2013) reviews evidence that one cause of the problem may be a fundamental deficit in the representation of numerosity. Geary describes three possible sources of a problem in children’s appreciation of number. To appreciate where the problems may lie, you need to know about the approximate number system. All children (and members of many other species) are born with an ability to appreciate numerosity. The approximate number system does not support precise counting, but allows for comparison judgements of “more than” or “less than.” For example, in the figure below you can tell at a glance (and without counting) which cloud contains more dots.  This ability –making the comparison without counting–is supported by the approximate number system. (Formal experiments control for things like the total amount of “dot material” in each field, and so on.) The ability depends not on the absolute difference in number of dots, but on the ratio. Adults can discriminate ratios as low as 11:10. Infants can perform this task, but the ratio of the difference in dots must be much greater, closer to 2:1. Many researchers believe that this approximate number system is the scaffold for an understanding of the cardinal values of number. So the first possible source of problems in mathematics may be that the approximate number system does not develop at a typical pace, leaving the child slow to develop the cognitive representations of quantity that can support mathematics. A second possibility is that the approximate number system works just fine, but the problem lies in associating symbols (number names and Arabic numerals) to the quantities represented there. Geary speculates that regulating attention may be particularly important to this ability. Finally, it is possible for children to appreciate the cardinal value of numbers and yet not understand the logical relationships among those numbers, to appreciate the structure as a whole. That’s the third possible problem. Geary suggests that there is at least suggestive evidence that each of these potential problems creates trouble for some students. The analogy to dyslexia is irresistible, and not inappropriate. Math, like reading, is not a “natural” human activity. It is a cultural contrivance, and the cognitive apparatus to support it must be hijacked from mental systems meant to support other activities. As such, it is fragile, meaning it lacks redundancy. If something goes wrong, the system as a whole functions very poorly. Thus, understanding how things might go wrong is essential to helping children who struggle early on. Source

Learning math is a lot like building a house. You can put up a single story hut on uneven ground, but if you plan on building up you will need a solid foundation. Since every new floor relies on the structure underneath it, you have to be diligent and make sure that things are done right. Any small error that pops up in the process will get compounded as the house grows in height. An uneven floor might go unnoticed in a two story house but your goals need to be much bigger than that if you plan on doing mathematics. Much like your house, mathematics is built on simple principles. There is nothing hard about it if you have an intuition for what's going on. Most people find it difficult because every new concept builds on previous knowledge. A single bad teacher or a few missed lectures can lead to problems with every topic that follows it. A child, for example, might get through algebra without understanding how to deal with fractions but it will make learning trigonometry much harder and that in turn will make learning calculus nearly impossible. The key here is to actually understand the ideas, something that most schools fail to get across. Instead, the focus is on teaching kids to memorize formulas and computational tricks that will help them finish standardized tests on time. Fortunately real math doesn't work that way, so don't waste your time memorizing and try to understand instead.

Just to add some diversity to the answers, I'll suggest a specific source of difficulty: I think misconceptions sometimes arise when learning a new mathematical topic due to terminology that overlaps with everyday language. Here are some examples:  "Real" versus "Imaginary" numbers. These words suggest that one type of number is somehow more legitimate, applicable, or meaningful than the other, obscuring the fact that they're just labels for certain mathematical concepts. What is "real" about the addition of an infinite sequence of numbers like 3+1/10+4/100+1/1000+5/10000+…3+1/10+4/100+1/1000+5/10000+…? Nothing, really. Just as the "imaginary" number ii is an invention to solve the equation x2=1x2=1, the "real" number ππ is an invention to represent the ratio of the diameter of a circle to its radius when measured with infinite precision (infinite precision = impossible). The mathematical concepts the terms apply to have little to do with the more familiar meanings of the word "imaginary" and "real". "Open" and "closed" sets in topology. The use of these terms in mathematics overlaps to some extent with how they are used in real life. It makes intuitive sense to think of a "closed" object as one that  "includes all its members", which is somehow what the mathematical definition is going for. Similarly for open. Yet, while it doesn't make sense in everyday language for something to be both open and closed, the empty set and the set of all real numbers are, according to the mathematical definition. You can think of this sort of terminology as the "false friends" when learning the language of mathematics. The everyday meaning of the word may be helpful for intuition and remembering the concept, but its important to not lose sight of the fact that it's just a label for a particular mathematical definition."Nonlinear equations". Usually this is short-hand for "not-necessarily linear equations". It's confusing that a linear equation is included in the set of equations labelled "nonlinear". This usage is sort of justified in that techniques that apply to some particular set of nonlinear phenomena are constructed so that they are generalizations of some corresponding technique for linear phenomena. For instance, there are theorems to determine when nonlinear control systems are "controllable" that generalize previously developed theorems for linear systems. Even so, the terminology may contribute to misunderstanding.It's true that this sort of confusion in terms happens when learning many fields, but in my opinion mathematics is more prone to it. Our everyday use of language is much more tolerant to ambiguity than mathematics is.  I think this problem also ties in to other issues that can lead to mathematics seeming more difficult to learn than it may otherwise be. In some sense it's true that to really understand a mathematical topic, you have to know and understand the definitions. This can sometimes lead instructors to overemphasize rigor in their presentation and neglect to put in effort that might make the subject more relatable. For instance, one might think to avoid the confusion mentioned above when discussing "open" versus "closed" it's better to simply present the definitions and not discuss how the everyday meaning of those words is connected. This is unfortunate, since that connection aids understanding and intuition, even if it doesn't perfectly map to the concept. This sort of phenomenon is exacerbated by the fact that the instructor has likely been comfortable with these concepts for so long that he or she may be more likely to fail to anticipate and address the difficulties faced by someone learning them for the first time.  That said, this is only a small piece of why many people find mathematics difficult to learn. I only bring it up because I think it's interesting to think about and possibly helpful to keep in mind when learning (at least it has been for me, personally).

The brain did not evolve to be a general-purpose computer, it evolved in response to specific recurring adaptive problems in ancestral environments, building adaptations on previous adaptations. Math ability and general intelligence factor are strongly related. General intelligence here is like general-purpose computer. The nature of consciousness is such that we don't generally perceive the computations of the mind (there is generally no evolved function to do so) and so our reasoning subjectively appears rational, intuitive, and seamless. This is precisely why Kahneman's work starting around 1972 is so important - starting with the standard cognitive psychology assumption that the mind is like a computer - logical and general-purpose, Kahneman and others documented many cognitive biases. Now evolutionary psychologists, really beginning with Cosmides in the 1980s working on cheater detection mechanisms of the mind (The Wason Selection Task) are working from the other direction, starting with the assumption of no mental structures unless they evolved (generally speaking). (See also Gerd Gigerenzer's work et al.) General intelligence factor is a very useful psychometrics tool, but ultimately the logic of William James writing around 1900 applies -- Humans have reason because we have more instincts, not less. i.e. "reasoning instincts" as Pinker writes about such as in The Language Instinct. Math is hard because our minds are kludged together from many evolved reasoning instincts not specifically designed/evolved for general purpose problems, or for math.

Mathematics is a language, albeit a universal language. Often, it can be hard to see past the “mathematical jargon”, which is unavoidable in written mathematics. Consider a person who can only speak English. Show that person a sentence in English, then the same sentence in Spanish. The English person will analyse the words in the Spanish sentence individually and eventually conclude what they believe the sentence as a whole means, whereas the English person will read the english sentence and understand what is written almost immediately. The ideas and reasonings behind the sentence are the same, but the language it is presented in is different. Still, it would likely take the English person far longer to properly understand the Spanish sentence, whereas it is immediately understood when presented in English. Now, apply this analogy to mathematics. A mathematician, who knows how to read, write an speak the language of mathematics can decipher a sentence “written in mathematics” (for want of a better phrase). But a student of mathematics, who is seeing this new presentation of an idea for the first time, will initially struggle and blunder their way through the sentence. For example, consider this simple idea: the distance a car travels in a given period of time indicates the speed (or velocity) of the car. We can rewrite this same sentence in terms of mathematics: Suppose y represents distance and x represents time, then dy/dx represents the speed of the car. Without first knowing about variables and derivatives the mathematics student won’t be able to understand the latter sentence as easily as they are able to read the former. This leads to a perceived difficulty. In some cases, it is enough to put the student off and thereby perpetuate the idea that “Maths is hard”.

I find that often a lot of things are left out of math explanations maybe for the sake of being concise and elegant. I was reading a proof on Quora the other day that there is no solution to y^2 = x^3–5. I have a background in mathematics but not in number theory. So the proof went, “assume there is a solution, reduce modulo 4. Then they point to a table of values for y^2 mod 4 and x^3–1 mod4. The table shows the remainder when y^2 is divided by 4 and when x^3–1 is divided by 4. So I’m thinking : why pick x^3–1 instead of x^3–5 like in the question. I guess I am missing out on some logic. So then I do an internet search for someone else to explain the solution and saw the same solution. So then I had a choice to think about it for another hour or to say hell with it and do something else and think ok, sometime I’ll have to study modular arithmetic and maybe my point of misunderstanding will come to me. So even for math people frustration arises when explanations are not clear because someone versed in the field assumes that everyone should be able to fill in the details. Of course for the purpose of publishing math results economy and short explanations are often best. The other extreme is of course too much explanation with hundreds of identical exercises for the reader to do and that’s just as bad and an equal time waster. Sometimes it seems that math is kind of a way to divide people into two groups, those that get it and those that don’t. The group consisting of those that don’t is very very large. When I was in University , some of the math profs would look down on Computer people as being quite stupid. It seems that some math exams were almost set to weed out those that were not truly into math to prove that they were stupid. So some of the blame for math difficulty may be in the elitist attitude of some academics. Practically when you teach a large group of students, it is of course hard to tailor the teaching to each student’s level of understanding. So a middle of the road approach is used which may bore the brightest and fail the less capable. Teaching math is always a hard challenge that a good teacher always strives to improve on.

response.answer_text: Math is hard for exactly the same reasons that poetry is hard. The point in each case is to effectively describe things that are difficult to put into words. They are in different domains, of course. Where poetry might try to describe a mood, mathematics might try to describe a curve, and while we all know what a mood feels like and a curve looks like, putting those things into words takes real effort. Poetry and mathematics both demand abstract thinkingPoetry and mathematics both demand attention to subtlety and detailPoetry and mathematics both demand that we stop looking at ‘things’ and start looking at the relationships between ‘things’And up until about the middle of high school, people who like poetry and mathematics get more or less the same kind of treatment from a coarse, literal-minded society. That doesn’t make math or poetry harder, it just makes them harder to enjoy. So yes, math (and poetry) is hard because it asks you to express yourself in new, unaccustomed ways. In a way, it is exactly the same problem a 1 year old child faces when s’he realizes s’he can’t just point at something and make a noise and expect to get it. It has to be the right noise (a word, a label, a description, a metaphor, an equation) to get the job done.

Math is difficult because most of us do not think in terms of mathematical concepts. People studying the humanities in particular. tend to apply the same thought process to math class as to history. It simply doesn’t work. The other problem is that some people think they can memorize how to solve problems. They fail to recognize that each problem may require a slightly different method. When you take a math class, pay attention to the principles. If you apply the applicable principle and apply it correctly, solving the problem is easy. The other factor is that math is like a brick wall. the lower bricks support those higher up. If you do not know math (adding and subtracting), you can not do algebra. If you do not know your algebra, you will be lost in geometry. If you do not have both algebra and geometry, you can not learn calculus. etc. Consider also that each new topic is strange to the beginner. Algebra is different and thus hard. so is geometry for the same reason. I thought calculus was very hard until I spent some time learning it. I am dyslexic. If I can learn math well enough to use it in industry and then to teach math, so can you. It is only as difficult as you think it is.

Let us talk about a Group in mathematics. From the Wikipedia : A group is a set, G, together with an operation⋅ (called the group law of G) that combines any two elements a and b to form another element, denoted a ⋅ b or ab. To qualify as a group, the set and operation, (G, ⋅), must satisfy four requirements known as the group axioms: Closure For all a, b in G, the result of the operation, a ⋅ b, is also in G. Associativity For all a, b and c in G, (a ⋅ b) ⋅ c = a ⋅ (b ⋅ c). Identity element There exists an element e in G such that, for every element a in G, the equation e ⋅ a = a ⋅ e = a holds. Such an element is unique , and thus one speaks of the identity element. Inverse element For each a in G, there exists an element b in G, commonly denoted by a1a1 (or −a, if the operation is denoted "+"), such that a ⋅ b = b ⋅ a = e, where e is the identity element. Okay, so far so good. We are ready to work on groups and for easy examples , you can already determine if they are groups. Congratulations, you have learned a little bit of Group theory ! ———————(1) But , wait ! Why did you learn it? I mean, what was the reason that some mathematicians randomly formed a structure like this ? Is it just what it seems at the face value, or is there an ulterior motive? And lastly , why the name group ? ———(2) If you end your association with mathematics at the point marked (1) , mathematics will seem to you like a boring , hard subject, a lot to memorize and in general , something that was build by the whims of people who had nothing better to do ( Who called themselves mathematicians) If you cover up to point (2) , the art will slowly be revealed to you. You’ll understand why they are interesting, and why mathematicians are artists painting on a canvas made of numbers. And more than that, you will see things in a different light. You will understand that addition, subtraction, multiplication and division, the operations you learned when you were a kid, the operations that still make up half your calculations aren’t special at all. Once you see them through and through, you will have the power to define your own operations, according to your will. Just to solve some problem. And you’ll know exactly how the operator behaves. Imagine the power that you’ll possess. I am not saying that mathematics will be easy after that. But there’ll be a difference. Mathematics , when properly understood ,and when you have proper tools at your disposal can be very much like a story of Sherlock Holmes. Is the mystery easy? Nah, its hard. Is it interesting? Its Christmas !

My answer is from the perspective of a lay man with high school level knowledge of Mathematics. I did take it as an elective in college but have never really used those higher concepts.  I was bad at Mathematics in school. Reason : I was told constantly that I am "brilliant" at the languages(my mother was a language teacher so she knew how to keep me interested and hence at the top of the class), good at Social Sciences(easy enough at school level with all that "eating by heart" and vomiting over in the examination) and Maths was one area that I needed to improve to be a topper. Sciences? I managed one way or the other - some concepts interested me, the ones that didn't were again learned by heart and vomited. As time progressed, the more I was asked to improve, the worse it got - at one point of time I had A+ in all subjects and a red mark in Mathematics. Now that I look back, I realize its no more difficult than a lot of other things I learnt to do over time.Cooking. Dancing. Swimming. Learning a new language. Out of pure curiosity, I took a couple of sessions with Khan Academy over the topics that had seemed impossible 15 years ago. Voila! I was able to solve questions without the slightest of issues. I have not become more brain active in these years - rather slower. Then what had changed? I was not worried about failing. I took my time and no one was telling me that I should be scared of the Maths monster. My learning? Maths is not difficult- at least no more than other disciplines. Its just that the higher level concept draws heavily or maybe totally from one or more concepts of the lower level - you miss one step and bam! there you go all the way down. In comparison you are not hurt as much if you miss on a concept in another discipline. Languages - miss a concept and you will get it (eventually) once you speak. Sciences - its mostly basics (till high school)  and at places where it is not the higher concept draws from just one lower concept. Easy enough to get that.You cannot "speak" Maths to learn a concept and the lack of clarity in one thing leads to failure in another. Chain reaction :) No amount of practice can bring in a concept if the lower rung of the ladder is missing. 99% of people/kids miss one or the other "Maths step" at one point or the other and they hit the wall. In retrospect, the people who told me about the Maths monster were scared themselves.  Unless they go back(or are rather taken back) to the basics and re-learn it remains that way. The fear gene is passed on from one generation to other and hence the cliche "Maths is difficult".

Mathematics is like an onion the size of the universe. Each person tries to peel it back layer by layer until they get to the end. However, there is no end, and most people run into a layer where they just don't get it. For most people, this is something like high school or college calculus. When students reach this point, their minds often take the approach, "Mathematics has gotten progressively harder over the years. I can't even take this, let alone something harder." As I said, this is usually high school. These people have never seen how diverse mathematics can be. They've done some basic algebra, and basic trigonometry, and now some basic calculus, and there is nothing to show them why they should even continue. Many of these people are bright enough that they could likely make a huge impact in number theory, field theory, and many different branches of algebra. However, they get to calculus, and they assume that because there is one branch of math that they are bad at, they will never be good at any of the others, so they stop trying  to be good at mathematics, and instead do something else. To summarize, the problem isn't that they couldn't be great, it's that they assume that they can't.

It depends on how it’s taught. But as a subject, mathematics has one major challenge that results in many people finding it difficult, and it’s this… …unlike history, or many other subjects, anyone will have major difficulties if they start falling behind. If they don’t stay up, they are quickly lost and most in that situation never, ever catch up. The problem is not uncorrectable, but it requires the student get help in going back and picking up whatever they failed to learn. One example is: how difficult calculus is. It isn’t just the conceptual challenge of calculus itself, but the fact that if you’re weak in any of the subjects leading UP to calculus — algebra, trig, analytic geometry—you’ll be in trouble trying to learn calculus. And then it gets worse from there. You can look up the most modern, state-of-the-art math concepts on wikipedia, for example, but the articles assume you already know a tremendous amount of subjects nearly as advanced. And this is a problem. It presumes that before you get to the “A” level of knowledge, for example, you must first get to the “A-” level. But if you’re only at the “B” or “C” level, then abandon hope, all ye who enter. For the math students who get all of it — probably people who never missed a single day of class and therefore never fell behind — perhaps they get a great sense of pride from knowing what leaves other people baffled. It’s a shame there aren’t more people dedicated to making mathematics more obvious.

The main reason is that how it was taught does not match with the things you like. So you didn’t learn enough math yet to make it interesting. Some people like some rock music so they want to learn to play that on a guitar. So you get very excited and sign up for lessons. Then you find lessons are very hard and are very boring because you have to learn to just play these stupid notes over and over again and all you want to do it just learn to play your favorite song. So then you think, ok hell with music. You are going to study art. So you sign up for art class. You want to draw all that cool Manga stuff to impress your friends. Then you find out the teacher just had you drawing circles for three classes. You didn’t want this. You want to draw cool action characters like Superman flying through the air and not stupid circle. So you conclude art is very stupid and boring. So then there is this chess guy at your school who won $1,000 in some chess tournament. So you ask him to teach you. It would be cool to be a world champ and beat everyone like in the movies. So he teaches you how all the pieces move and a few tricks and you try that on some of your friends and lose. So then you conclude that guy doesn’t know how to teach and makes chess very boring and dumb. With math, you have to learn a lot of basic stuff before you can do anything with it. Suppose you want to write a cool computer game where you have explosions and you can shoot stuff and have all kinds of neat graphics. You want to do that. You know that some of these games made some teens super rich. So then you find out you need to know a programming language and you also need to know stuff about geometry and algebra before you can do anything. But before you can understand algebra and geometry you need to really know your arithmetic but you thought arithmetic was totally boring. So you decide hell with writing computer games. Computer games are stupid anyway, except for playing them. Everything seems to require too much work before you can do anything. well that’s how the world works.

It depends what you mean by difficult, and on who you are. First natural talent helps. Just as it's very hard to be a 5' tall NBA player, you can definitely have or not have an aptitude towards mathematics. But more importantly, more than almost any other subject you will study, maths is progressive and builds on what you have done before. To illustrate if you for whatever reason miss a year of History class there is going to be an area of history you know nothing about and a few techniques that you might have to pick up from others. But you'll only struggle a little most of the time. If you miss a year of Math class most of what you need to know the next year builds on what you learned the previous year and you are going to be floundering throughout the next year. If you miss work in math class you can not afford to not catch it up in the way you can in most other classes. On the other hand this means that if you make sure you miss nothing out math is probably easier than most other classes because so many people do miss steps out and then find themselves struggling. And it's hard to look back and see where you've actually missed something because it was almost certainly one or two steps before you actually started to struggle. Put the work in to keep up and you'll find that the people who get by on ability while not working struggle while you find it easy. So is it difficult? No - but it does require you to be thorough in a way few other subjects do.

My college degree is in mathematics. Why mathematics? Because I felt then and still do now that it would be far easier if not impossible to learn it on my own. History, English literature, etc. I could read, study and learn in near solitude. Mathematics is made more difficult by authors who don’t know the subject well enough, and often not at all, to describe it in textbooks. Then you have art history majors made into math teachers in a Summer’s course. How the hell can you learn math? It can be rather daunting. Your parents usually can’t offer help because about twice a decade a whole new math approach arrives in your school district. Then we have group problem solving. Usually even worse than the U.S. Congress. Some classrooms in grade school don’t offer two or three levels of instruction. Wouldn’t want to hurt someone’s self esteem. So the class is taught at the level of least knowledgeable or interested student. So much for learning what is required by the grade level. Lastly, math is given short minutes each week in class. Students know more about minority contributions to their local area than about math. We teach both the US system, similar to the British imperial system, and the metric system. The metric system doesn’t relate well to the everyday world and is difficult to use in everyday measurements. The US system relates easily to the world around us but is not used by most of the world. Math is easy if textbooks are well written and teachers competent. Neither, I fear, happens on a regular basis. Don’t despair, someday you’ll will find that inspiring math teacher and learn.

From an evolutionary perspective, our abilities in abstract reasoning, including mathematics, are a comparatively recent development. Most of us are highly skilled in terms of our ability to perceive and interact with the physical world, but this comes so naturally we often don't even really consider it. This problem is very well illustrated in the field of Artificial Intelligence and specifically Moravec's paradox.  According to Moravec, "Encoded in the large, highly evolved sensory and motor portions of the human brain is a billion years of experience about the nature of the world and how to survive in it. The deliberate process we call reasoning is, I believe, the thinnest veneer of human thought, effective only because it is supported by this much older and much more powerful, though usually unconscious, sensorimotor knowledge. We are all prodigious olympians in perceptual and motor areas, so good that we make the difficult look easy. Abstract thought, though, is a new trick, perhaps less than 100 thousand years old. We have not yet mastered it. It is not all that intrinsically difficult; it just seems so when we do it."

Math is unforgiving. Unlike most other subjects, math leaves no room for error. There may be more than one way to do something, but once you’ve chosen what to do, you’re either right or wrong. Students don’t have the liberty of hearing “you almost got it.”Math is cumulative. In a history or English class, every new year is like a reset button. No one assumes any prior knowledge. In math, if you messed up two years ago, it will come back to haunt you.Math is taught differently. In English, you learn what a sentence is before you learn about its parts. You hear stories before you write sentences. So, when you learn about what a verb is, it fits. Math is taught to you like a jigsaw puzzle. We start with addition. And then multiplication. And then algebra. And then calculus. And finally, after calculus, you might start to see how any of it can be applied to the real world. Being taught mathematics is being given the pieces to a 1000 piece jigsaw puzzle, only to be shown the big picture 10 years later.Math incites fear. “Math is hard” is a trope. Children are taught from a young age that math is a challenge. So the ones that get it feel great. But the ones that don’t feel justified. It’s okay not to be good at math because it’s “hard.” Unfortunately, math only gets harder once you’ve decided that you can’t/won’t do it.Math is boring. Okay. Math isn’t always boring. But staring at something that you don’t understand at all for an hour is boring. And trying to learn something that is boring is hard. So learning math is hard. (How’s that for some first order logic?)

Mathematics isn’t for everyone. Some of us are very ‘logical’ people that can memorize a set of rules and follow that set to the last step, but others aren’t as fortunate. Everyone has strengths in some fields and weaknesses in others. If you asked me to translate 555 into base-6 using mathematics, I’d tell you the answer is 2323, but if you asked me to draw a lamp, I’d fail horrendously. Struggling with mathematics doesn’t mean that we’re stupid or less intelligent than others, it just means that we need more practice in that certain area. Hell, it could even be dyscalculia! Don’t let anyone try to bring you down or make you feel stupid just because you can’t calculate the rate of volume change, or the increase in decibels in Fluffles the cat’s meows as she climbs higher and higher in a tree. According to this article, about 70% of all college students are required to enroll in remedial math, so struggling with mathematics isn’t rare, it’s quite common. The societal norms of ‘measuring intelligence’ based on STEM skills is quite oppressing for those that have talents and skills in other areas. So, to answer your question, why is studying mathematics so difficult? It’s simply because you’re not a math person. You may be a wunderkind in writing poetry, researching animals’ habits, painting, or dance; but math just isn’t your strong suit.

In our society ,mathematics is seen as a difficult and demanding subject, and those students who are supposedly born with a gift of “math genius” can know Mathematics, and the rest suffer from a serious maths mental block; but is this mental block more of a whimsical excuse as it is common that outside school, most of us can do perfect Mathematics but when it comes to formal equations and formulas within the classroom, then we as students get scared? Is the answer to this question as simple as saying that Mathematics in our school is not linked directly to the real context of everyday mathematical uses we apply in our daily life. There could be numerous reasons as why mathematics is perceived as a hard subjects than others, some of the reasons are :- Conceptually, many topics of mathematics are integrated with each other, for example concept of carry over or carry forward is somehow connected with the concept of PLACE VALUE. So without knowing the concept of place value, learners find difficulties in addition with carry forward, again in case of subtraction,multiplication and division too.Rote memorized rules and manipulation of symbols with little or no meaning are harder to learn than integrated conceptual structure.Poor pedagogical practices are one of the major reason in understanding math, as teachers put too much emphasis on memorizing formula and are dealing with traditional standard algorithms for the four basic operations and its related word problem.So in order to understand Maths well, one of the important aspect of the pedagogy should be “EXPERIENTIAL” and let the learners to learn the concepts through concrete ways , which could be done doing activities using concrete physical tools . once the learners develops a concrete understanding of the concept, we can move towards abstraction of the experiential learning and it will help the learner to mathematize his/her learning.

Ok, I’ll take a stab at that. It’s because mathematics is, in a sense, trivial. It’s trivial because it does not involve discovering anything about the world, taking measurements, or doing experiments. It’s just about things that are logically equivalent. That’s the relationship between a theorem and axioms. They just follow logically. It should be totally obvious. But it isn’t. Because we just aren’t that smart. No one. At least no one so far. Our brains aren’t really wired that way. That’s why, for example, we see optical illusions, or sometimes trip on stuff. We’re wired to know stuff based on experience, not logic. It’s really hard to think logically, just like it’s a lot harder to interpret the phrase “bird sitting on a toadstool” than to interpret a picture of a bird sitting on a toadstool. Maybe a lot of theorems would be obvious to a far more advanced creature, just as a lot of things are obvious to us, that just aren’t obvious to a dog. So, mathematics is hard because it deals with stuff that should be obvious, because it follows logically, but it isn’t, because we just ain’t that smart nor wired for it. Mathematics is a crutch to extend our minds, but it’s a hard crutch to use. Think of a dog riding a bicycle. It’s unnatural. It’s hard. Not all of them can do it, and fewer can do it well. The difference, though, is that mathematics is useful because it can connect things that aren’t obvious to us naturally.

I did very well up until "New Math" started when I was in 5th grade.  Suddenly, it no longer mattered how I did a problem, or what answer I got, but whether or not I understood the concept behind the function. Huh? After that, I was lost, mathematically.  It seemed that I only understood what I learned the year after I learned it, when I was then lost in the next year. I never 'got' math-  it was always, always a struggle.   In college Algebra II, the instructor had a double masters-  one in Mathematics, one in Logic.  He taught us in Greek-  literally.  He'd cover the boards in Greek symbols and numbers while we frantically scribbled, trying to understand AND keep up with what he was writing, then he'd come to the end of the equation and say, "Well, there's a mistake in the arithmetic somewhere- don't worry about it" and erase the whole thing! I remember the night before an exam on ratios and proportions, I dreamed the problems all night long.  I was aware enough in the dream to know I didn't have a pencil or paper, so I had to do these long, long divisions in my head, remember where the decimals went in my head, no pencil, no eraser, all in my head.  One of the worst nights of sleep I have had in my life. I pulled a B on the exam;  but I still shudder at doing ratios and percentages. I am very good at many things, but I am not good at math.  Perhaps it is the way I was taught for a few years, perhaps it is not a bent I have.  I believe talent comes in more subjects than simply the arts.  I think mathematical ability is a talent no less than the ability to draw, or sing, or play a musical instrument.  A person may have the talent, the bent, but still must be taught enough, or, better, led towards, an ability to explore for themselves.  I never had that-  math was always torture.  I know why I don't like maths, and it's because, despite trying over and over, I'm not good at it.

I think the single biggest reason that anyone finds mathematics difficult is communication. You might think this is the same for any subject, not only mathematics, and to some extent it is true, but with mathematics there are certain built in obstacles.What makes mathematics glamorous and fascinating to those that love it are all those amazing symbols, and squiggles, that makes you part of the club when you proudly start writing them on a pad or whiteboard. The new, and special language that makes the subject so alive is for many the first problem. So if you are frightened a starting place could be to ask the more confident to slow down, and explain those symbols, and markings on the whiteboard. If you don't like the new symbols practice, and don't be frightened to make a fool of yourself, because whoever you are, sooner or later, you will get it wrong! I remember choosing to study at one particular university because I'd read some of the papers written by one of the lecturers. I sat through their lectures full of enthusiasm, but it has to be said they made many blunders, but they could be forgiven because they approached everything with such grace, and I learnt so much from their approach to the subject.Even putting the symbols to one side there are still the words that are often so frightening, words like hypotenuse, perpendicular, differentiation, integration, mutually exclusive, indeterminate, axiomatic, modulo, lemma, corrolory, theorem and the list goes on and on. Again knowing how the words came about can add a deepness to the subject that many educators either don't know or are too busy to mention. Yet some explanation of a word could add a new handle and dimension to the subject.So let's put both the symbols and the words to one side, why else might some find the mathematical domain daunting and difficult? Mathematics seems to have an endless number of rules that you have to stick to or else! This is true it does have a lot to remember when using it, it can be particularly off putting to have worked hard on something only to find it is wrong because of a slip right at the beginning of the work. However, imagine listening to your favourite song and the singer or band member started dropping notes all over the place. Would that be acceptable? Mathematics needs to be exact, because it deals with things that need an exact answer. How many times would you want to listen to nonsensical music before your nerves became completely jangled? If you think about it the rules actually make the subject accessible. If you get the rules, and apply them correctly, you get the right answer. There is no argument, unlike other subjects.Remember that essay you wrote for English or History that time, you know the one you thought was perfect? You got in back and the grade appeared to be subterranean, you read your classmates version and you couldn't tell the difference, but their grade is stratospheric. Well perhaps there were very subtle differences, but you couldn't tell and what's more subjectity could have been at work. This will not happen in mathematics, not at the majority of levels in any case.So if we put the strange symbols, words, and rules to one side what else makes mathematics difficult? Well beyond a solid understanding of arithmetic most people don't have to use mathematics in their everyday life. We are continuously talking and so our verbal skills are continuously updated. The internet constantly tells us what is happening in the world and we use this as currency when conversing. Mathematics is fairly invisible to most people, but it is in fact everywhere! Telecommunications, aviation, commerce, modern medicine, geological exploration, and just about everything that means a thing has mathematics at its core. If these areas interest you then start turning on your mathematical thinking, we all have it!

Maths is difficult or not depends on how your approach is towards studies. Some people love to learn stories and so they like history. They find it amazing who was who, while some people do not want to mug-up things at all. They just believe in learning few formulas and use it to solve problems ( while this is what elementary maths is) At college level you will need to memorize and mug up few derivations etc. Maths itself is a vast subject. Linear algebra, calculas , geometry, abstract maths etc. Linear algebra is one of the easiest to understand. I’m not sure what kind of mathematics you mean. There are two possibilities. Since you’re not being specific, it’s likely that you’re talking about primary or secondary mathematics, or maybe 100- or 200-level college classes. In this case, the answer is: Because you were taught poorly, and therefore lack self-efficacy. You should apply the following general approach of making sense of a novel mathematics problem. Find a way to turn the mathematical abstraction into a concrete, real-world problem. If you don’t know how to do this on your own, use the Google. You could alternately type the problem into the comment section below, and I’d be happy to help you with this.Draw a picture.Think about it.Reduce the problem to a simpler one with smaller numbers or fewer features, if that helps.Formulate your best guess.Talk to other people about it.Repeat on similar problems until the operation or concept is familiar.The more problems you solve and new concepts you understand intuitively, the stronger your self-efficacy will become, and the more comfortable you will feel tackling new challenges. On the other hand, maybe you’re talking about advanced mathematics. In that case, the answer is, because it takes a long time to solve the problems and understand the material. And unless you’re a grad student in mathematics, or a researcher in a related domain, you probably have other things to do with each day’s 24 hours, so you don’t have time to make sense of it. Also, the books are expensive, and there aren’t many resources on the internet, so it’s harder to get a good explanation without investing money or your indentured servitude in grad school.

Math is unforgiving. Unlike most other subjects, math leaves no room for error. There may be more than one way to do something, but once you’ve chosen what to do, you’re either right or wrong. Students don’t have the liberty of hearing “you almost got it.”Math is cumulative. In a history or English class, every new year is like a reset button. No one assumes any prior knowledge. In math, if you messed up two years ago, it will come back to haunt you.Math is taught differently. In English, you learn what a sentence is before you learn about its parts. You hear stories before you write sentences. So, when you learn about what a verb is, it fits. Math is taught to you like a jigsaw puzzle. We start with addition. And then multiplication. And then algebra. And then calculus. And finally, after calculus, you might start to see how any of it can be applied to the real world. Being taught mathematics is being given the pieces to a 1000 piece jigsaw puzzle, only to be shown the big picture 10 years later.Math incites fear. “Math is hard” is a trope. Children are taught from a young age that math is a challenge. So the ones that get it feel great. But the ones that don’t feel justified. It’s okay not to be good at math because it’s “hard.” Unfortunately, math only gets harder once you’ve decided that you can’t/won’t do it.Math is boring. Okay. Math isn’t always boring. But staring at something that you don’t understand at all for an hour is boring. And trying to learn something that is boring is hard. So learning math is hard. (How’s that for some first order logic?)

In order to really understand math, you must really be able to visualize the concepts as you read them, without ever having visualized something like that before. This is a very difficult challenge and why few are blessed with the ability to really grasp advanced mathematics. The presence of highly abstract concepts that are difficult (if not impossible) to relate to real-life examples is one of many reasons that math is so hard, and yet so beautiful

Math is like sports. When you’re learning to play a sport, is it enough to read books about the sport, memorize some facts, and maybe watch movies about it? Of course not! With sports you learn by doing. It’s the same in math: you can’t just read the book, you have to do the practice problems (homework). Math is like sports in another way. If you want to be good at basketball, do you practice only right before a game? No, youpractice every day or almost every day. It’s the same with math: you have to keep your “mental muscles” limber by working with it every day. Math is like foreign languages. When you study a foreign language, you know there will be a lot of words you don’t know. The same is true in math, except that many of the words look like English words. But math terms like set, prove, hypothesis, term, solution have special meanings that are different from ordinary English. Approach math like a foreign language and make sure you understand every term. It might be helpful to build up a vocabulary list in your notebook. Math is like science or engineering. You need to be very meticulous and work everything out logically. There may be different ways to get to the right answer, but there’s only one right answer. Math is like building construction. When you’re building a house, you would never think of trying to put up the second floor before the first floor. Building is asequential process. The same is true in math: each concept builds on the ones that came before. In history, you can understand the Depression pretty well even if you didn’t study World War I. But in math it’s different: you need to understand factoring very well or you won’t be able to solve equations. This means that if you’re strapped for time, the one course that’s most dangerous to let slide is your math course. With other courses, if you don’t understand day 11 you can probably follow the lecture on day 12. With math, you have to understand day 11 or you’ll likely be lost in day 12. The moral is that you need to stay current. If ever you don’t understand something, get help on it right away. Otherwise you’ve just knocked away the first floor of your house, and you know what that will do when you try to put up the second floor. Hope this helps..
