Math is tough. This is a common problem in the student community. To do away with this, please follow the writeup below. Life is a perpetual instruction in cause and effect.” ― Ralph Waldo Emerson. Mathematics is a subject that deals with analysis, computation and evaluation, respectively. The three aspects can be related to initiation, propagation and termination of a certain quantity. It is the step by step method to achieve a logical conclusion. Mathematics fear or math anxiety is a real problem that most of the students face today. It is an anxiety about one’s ability to do mathematics. According to Mark H. Ashcraft, maths anxiety is “a feeling of tension, apprehension, or fear that interferes with math performance”. A student may believe he or she is incapable of doing mathematics problems before attempting the problem or even before the teacher explains the problem.A student may have a bad attitude about mathematics. When he in mathematics class, he may be nervous and unable to sit still or focus on the lecture.Math-anxious students may dread even going to mathematics class. There is a greater fear of answering a teacher's question incorrectly in mathematics class than other classes.They also tend to compare their grades to their peers' more and worry more about how their peers will react to them if they give a wrong answer in mathematics class.Students may experience math anxiety because they have never experienced success in their mathematics classes. This can be due to poor instruction. If the teacher does not teach well, the average student will most likely not do well in his class.Also, the student may have taken an insufficient number of mathematics classes, causing him to be unprepared for the class he is in. This could especially be a problem in schools where teachers are very strongly discouraged from failing their students. It is possible for students to be in a mathematics class that they should not be in because they did not pass the previous class.Math anxiety begins at different ages for different people. Some students may experience it as early as third or fourth grade.The crux of math anxiety is thought to occur in middle school when students experience increasing social pressures.The major causes of mathematics anxiety or fear are as follows: Mathematics is Abstract- The subject is abstract in nature and I feel that Vedic Maths Tricks and Shortcuts can help us to reduce Maths fear to a greater extent.Teaching Methodology- Conventional system of teaching lacks innovation and makes the subject, dull and boring. Students fail to understand and visualize the concept. Gradually, the interest from the subject decreases.Formulations of mathematical equations- Formulation of mathematical equations require good analytical ability. It is not possible to learn mathematics like other subjects.Poor Command over Tables- Table is an integral part in developing fundamentals. A survey was conducted and it was found that a good number of students had poor command.Poor Trainers- A poor trainer neither enjoys the subject nor makes it’s interesting for his pupil.There are certain tips and tricks (i.e. solutions) for doing away with maths fear. I commonly name them as ‘LAB-ID’ which is nothing but a model that helps in reduction and eventually removal of maths anxiety or fear. a) [I] Identification- Identifying the problem is a main thing before getting its solution. It is natural to get multiple methods to solve a particular problem but it should never confuse us. The main motive of an individual should be to solve the sum/problem accordingly without any ambiguity. The method that takes less time and memory should be followed. For example, if we are given a problem to sum the numbers, then we must understand that it works on discrete values while integration should not be implemented here as it involves summation of continuous values. b) [D] Daily Practice- The most essential step is to practice daily. Scientific study shows that daily practice may lead to a state of mind where there will no doubt and at times, an individual delivers his best. c) [L] Learning from Mistakes- One who learns from his mistakes are the ones who shine in life like anything. They never look back to anything. They gain experience from failure and try not to repeat the same mistakes again and again. Math fear will fly away without any second thought! d) [A] Asking doubts from Mentors- Clarification of doubts is an integral part as well. We should always remember that ‘Doubts are never meant to be unsolved’. We should always approach our mentors or teachers to clear them. The more we are away from doubts, the chances of getting success, multiplies exponentially. e) [B] Being Confident- Being confident is a deterministic approach. Suppose an individual is given a multiple choice question with three options. He chooses one option with determination and confidence and gets it correct. Then, he or she is referred to be deterministic. For any number of situations, the output that is obtained is singular or unary in nature and type. Unlike all other phobia, this is also very detrimental in student community. The best way to avoid such psychological tantrum is to focus on our basics or fundamentals from the very beginning of the session. Essentially mathematics is about working with abstractions. (In the domain of mathematics) Except for counting, probably nothing else is an absolute necessity for human survival (as far as I can think of). Abstraction is always a pain (at first at least) as things abstracted are not easily graspable. Let me try to elaborate - We are driven to learning by necessity. What we find useful, or whatever we desire, we try to learn how to obtain it. If you are interested in making money, you will eventually learn about credit, taxation etc. - and the concepts/rules that govern them will make sense to you (just an example). We interact with people and the physical world for fulfilling our needs and desires. When it comes to people, mathematics is irrelevant :-P And as for the physical world (whose importance is only secondary in comparison), we deal with it intuitively - I don’t need mathematics to manipulate the physical world to suit my requirements. It is only when civilization progressed that mathematics got applied to the physical world in the form of (mathematically represented) models (e.g. Newton’s laws of motion). But only a minority need to understand science and use this in their work. So necessity to understand mathematics (that forms a basis for us humans with finite minds) is not present. My essential argument is there is not much of a natural incentive to learn mathematics :) Personally, I am not a great fan of mathematics. But with time I have come to realise (and there are many others who would agree with me on this, I’m sure) that essential to mathematics is the mathematical way of reasoning. It is the logical reasoning that is its essential takeaway. It teaches us to start with assumptions and build upon them (via implications). This can be applied to anything. Computer scientists/engineers for example apply it every day, every minute at their jobs. Every profession which requires significant “investment on thought” would require it. Why, philosophy is much about this skill, secondary only to experience (IMHO). Mathematics can be thought of as a playground for you to experiment, learn and sharpen your analytical skills. They will be required by anyone - only, to varying extent. This I know is no inspiring essay to get started on mathematics. All I am saying here is - if what you desire would require mathematics for understanding, it would start making sense to you someday…at least to some extent. Till then it would be only a bunch of formulas, theorems, rules that God only knows who invented and that you’d have to memorize (and forget the minute the final exam got over) to get through to the next class :-D But if this answer made some sense to you (hopefully it did), do take some subject/topic (or thing) you like and try to explore the mathematics behind it. It would make sense. Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow or the next month - but at least in 10 or 20 years from now. Do remember to upvote my answer whenever it does .

No, and anybody who says otherwise has been reading the other answers. I never had any trouble with maths, whether it was Fletcher & Fletcher books at primary school, Johnny Ball - Think Of A Number - Flight , or university maths. arXiv maths poses no problem, etc. Why? Because I learned several things that make a difference. First, “New Math" is only good for people who think in those terms. Which is almost nobody. Second, Rule Zero. Draw a diagram! Yes, diagrams. Those things people are supposed to abhor. Well, at least a certain French group abhored. Diagrams are absolutely essential to the correct understanding of mathematics. Third, you can turn any problem you don't understand into a problem you do understand. We usually use formula sheets, as books have a better memory than people, people are best left to things people do well. Fourth, write down all the steps/show your working. Skipping steps is a good way to lose track of things. Fifth, check results. These steps will let you go from start to finish with any problem. It doesn't matter if you're doing triple integrals, horribly complex Boolean algebra (important in encryption), partial differential equations, set theory (if you've never written software in Z, you've missed out), pi calculus, or Laplace transforms, you can ALWAYS make the problem one you can trivially do. Usually, the diagram is enough to do this. Nor does it matter if the problem is signals theory, fractals or sound processing. Those are all just details. The great thing about maths is that details don't matter. They can be converted into something else.

I wouldn’t say mathematics is inherently difficult; in a sense, it’s as easy as we can make it. However: It’s rather unintuitive for most people, once you get to more advanced topics, because the abstraction makes it seem quite far removed from everyday experiences. Humans happen to be capable of advanced maths, but it’s a consequence of our general cognitive abilities and not something we faced evolutionary pressure to be specifically good at (unlike, say, recognizing faces and facial expressions, which is an extremely complex task that most of us are good at as a result of evolution). You develop an intuition, but it takes time and effort, and it’s often based on imperfect analogies.Mathematics *research* is difficult, because you’re working at the frontier of human knowledge: nobody else knows the answers, and often nobody even knows what the right questions are. But all research is difficult and mathematics is not exceptional in this regard.Mathematics is highly structured. If you learn it as a haphazard collection of facts and recipes without trying to organize your knowledge, you will quickly get overwhelmed, but if you understand the structure, the raw quantity of information you need to retain is much less. Being forced to remember a deluge of unorganized information up to the limit of your ability, leaving no room for deeper comprehension, is not education but rather a kind of cognitive torture. ‘Cramming’ may help you pass the next exam, but it does you no favours in the long run.The subject is horribly misrepresented in many countries due to wider cultural problems (with the Anglo-Saxon world being an especially bad example). Maths has an unfortunate reputation in many countries of being uniformly difficult and only something those who are ‘gifted’ can get to grips with. (You can throw in sexist and racist stereotyping on top of this as to who the ‘gifted’ people are.) This becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy, as students develop an anxiety around maths which inhibits their ability to learn, causing them to fall further behind what the system expects of them, and so on. Even worse, many of the people *teaching* maths in school suffer from a fear and lack of understanding of maths and pass that on to their students. Worse still, teachers are controlled by a chain of managers going all the way up to government ministers who have even less understanding of maths, and these managers demand that the students be taught a bunch of recipes in order to pass the next exam (which the managers foolishly take as some sort of ‘benchmark’ of mathematical aptitude).

I think part of the problem is the way it is taught, at all levels. If you can think back to when you were 2 or 3 in the kindergarten. You were probably given a toy to experiment with. It would have different shapes like triangles, circles, squares etc. You would also have a tool with a solid form of these shapes. You would naturally try to fit the solid tool into the shapes. Also, you would probably have had a simple jig-saw puzzle of maybe 6 pieces and, with some prompting, manage to fit the pieces together. You were doing mathematics! Fast forward a bit until “real” school starts at about 5 (in England). In the “mathematics” lessons you learnt your times table off by heart (well this was 60+ years ago, maybe now it has changed.) This is NOT mathematics. If you were taught this way, did you understand anything at all about numbers? Can you explain the difference between Roman numbers and the Arab/Indian system we use to-day? Can you write a number as a partial sum? What about conversion between different number bases? At a young age I learnt to read a clock but I had no idea about modular arithmetic until much later. I am not sure if doing a lot of exercises is necessarily the answer. I think a better approach is self (or indeed group) discovery with the teacher acting more as a coach. Obviously the teacher has to impart some knowledge but maybe should not give the answers immediately. For example in an algebra class, the teacher can tell the story of Gauss and finding a simple way to add up consecutive numbers. But then he can ask: what about squares and then, of course, cubes are particular interesting, why? From this he can introduce ideas of linear algebra, calculus and induction. How many times have you seen totally pointless sequence questions? Induction is such an important topic, I think, it should be introduced before the undergraduate stage. I experienced too much of a jump between the always solvable questions of school mathematics and the abstraction of pure maths and the real world problems of applied mathematics. The other difficulty to overcome is the language. There is a standard basic language of mathematics using symbols and words which have special meanings. These change over the years so you need to recognize and understand them. In more advanced topics there seems to be a tendency to create mathematical gobbledygook. I recently tried to read a paper on p-adic numbers but did not understand a single word. Surely it can’t be that difficult. As a software engineer, I used a basically 2-adic number structure for about 35 years!

Mathematics (fromGreek μάθημα máthēma, "knowledge, study, learning") includes the study of such topics as quantity(number theory) structure(algebra), and change(mathematical analysis) It has no generally accepted definitionMathematicians seek and use patterns to formulate new conjectures; they resolve the truth or falsity of conjectures by mathematical proof. When mathematical structures are good models of real phenomena, then mathematical reasoning can provide insight or predictions about nature. Through the use of abstraction and logic, mathematics developed from counting, calculation, measurement, and the systematic study of the shapes motions of physical objects. Practical mathematics has been a human activity from as far back as written records exist. The research required to solve mathematical problems can take years or even centuries of sustained inquiry. Rigourous arguments first appeared in Greek mathematics, most notably in Euclid ‘elements. Since the pioneering work of Giuseppe Pagano(1858–1932), David Hilbert(1862–1943), and others on axiomatic systems in the late 19th century., it has become customary to view mathematical research as establishing truthby rigorous deduction from appropriately chosen axioms and definitions. Mathematics developed at a relatively slow pace until the Renaissreance, when mathematical innovations interacting with new scientific discoveries to a rapid increase in the rate of mathematical discovery that has continued to the present day. Mathematics is essential in many fields, including natural sciences, engineering, medicine, finance, and the social sciences. Applied mathematics to entirely new mathematical disciplines, such as statistics and game theory. Mathematicians engage in pure mathematics(mathematics for its own sake) without having any application in mind, but practical applications for what began as pure mathematics are often discovered later. In 2005, Gallup conducted a poll that asked students to name the school subject that they considered to be the most difficult. Not surprisingly, mathematics came out on top of the difficulty chart. So what is it about math that makes it difficult? Have you ever wondered? This definition gets to the crux of the problem when it comes to math, specifically the statement that a difficult task is one that is not “readily” done. The thing that makes math difficult for many students is that it takes patience and persistence. For many students, math is not something that comes intuitively or automatically - it takes plenty of effort. It is a subject that sometimes requires students to devote lots and lots of time and energy. This means, for many, the problem has little to do with brainpower; it is mostly a matter of staying power. And since students don't make their own timelines when it comes to "getting it," they can run out of time as the teacher moves on to the next topic. Math and Brain Types But there is also an element of brain-style in the big picture, according to many scientists. There will always be opposing views on any topic, and the process of human learning is subject to ongoing debate, just like any other topic. But many theorists believe that people are wired with different math comprehension skills. According to some brain science scholars, logical, left-brain thinkers tend to understand things in sequential bits, while artistic, intuitive, right-brainers are more global. They take in a lot of information at one time and let it "sink in." So left-brain dominant students may grasp concepts quickly while right-brain dominant students don’t. To the right brain dominant student, Math as a Cumulative Discipline Math know-how is cumulative, which means it works much like a stack of building blocks. You have to gain understanding in one area before you can effectively go on to “build upon” another area. Our first mathematical building blocks are established in primary school when we learn rules for addition and multiplication, and those first concepts comprise our foundation. The next building blocks come in middle school when students first learn about formulas and operations. This information has to sink in and become “firm” before students can move on to enlarge this framework of knowledge. The big problem starts to appear sometime between middle school and high school because students very often move on to a new grade or new subject before they’re really ready. Students who earn a “C” in middle school have absorbed and understood about half of what they should, but they move on anyway. They move on or are moved on, because They think a C is good enough.Parents don’t realize that moving on without a full understanding poses a big problem for high school and college.Teachers don’t have time and energy enough to ensure that every single student understands every single concept.So students move to the next level with a really shaky foundation. The outcome of any shaky foundation is that there will be a serious limitation when it comes to building and real potential for complete failure at some point. The lesson here? Any student who receives a C in a math class should review heavily to make sure to pick up concepts they'll need later. In fact, it is smart to hire a tutor to help you review any time you find that you have struggled in a math class. Making Math Less Difficult We have established a few things when it comes to math and difficulty: Math seems difficult because it takes time and energy.Many people don't experience sufficient time to "get" math lessons, and they fall behind as the teacher moves on.Many move on to study more complex concepts with a shaky foundation.We often end up with a weak structure that is doomed to collapse at some point.Although this may sound like bad news, it is really good news. The fix is pretty easy if we’re patient enough! No matter where you are in your math studies, you can excel if you backtrack far enough to reinforce your foundation. You must fill in the holes with a deep understanding of the basic concepts you encountered in middle school math. If you’re in middle school right now, do not attempt to move on until you understand pre-algebra concepts fully. Get a tutor if necessary.If you’re in high school and struggling with math, download a middle school math syllabus or hire a tutor. Make sure you understand every single concept and activity that is covered in middle grades.If you’re in college, backtrack all the way to basic math and work forward. This won’t take as long as it sounds. You can work forward through years of math in a week or two.No matter where you start and where you struggle, you must make sure you acknowledge any weak spots in your foundation and fill the holes with practice and understanding!

Are you memorizing or are you really trying to understand? It is possible that you have fundamental difficulties with symbolic logic (such as that which is used in algebra), and that is totally fine. But if you are struggling to understand why you are doing what the hell you are doing, then you are not truly understanding what is going on behind the scene with all the mathematical machinery, and you are not alone. Math is a powerful lens through which we may analyze and create, and if you read between the fine lines you will see that reality is inscribed in the language of mathematics (and in many different dialects of mathematics!) So take the time to truly understand why your teacher and textbooks define things the way they do, and you can literally wield math like a sword. Who said that only they have a monopoly on math? The greatest mathematicians in history never accepted what they were told as fact; they either had an intuitive understanding of what was going on, or forced themselves to gain such an intuition all on their own!

response.answer_text: Mathematics uses explicit and precise rules, definitions, and structures. There is no wiggle room. Either a=b or it doesn’t. If you are used to discussions where you can sway people to your way of thinking about a book or a philosophy, then these will not work in mathematics. English words can have several different meanings or shades of meanings, but mathematics has very set definitions for words. You can change the definition but then the mathematical system you are working in will change, which means you won’t be able to work in the old system unless you change back. If you can think this way, you will find mathematics easy; if not, then you will continually have trouble.

Math is hard! Hard like a diamond — rigid, unyielding, crystalline, rigorous! Math is the pure expression of logic and reason, and the only source of unambiguous truth. Math is supposed to be hard. If you don’t think math is hard, then you haven’t learned very much math. Everyone hits some point where they say to themselves, yikes, this is hard. That might happen in elementary school, and it might not happen until university. But, it will happen. And part of the satisfaction of mathematics comes when a student pushes through the frustration and has an “ah-ha” moment. If it wasn’t hard then no “ah-ha” and really very little joy. It is impossible to appreciate the beauty and the elegance of mathematics unless you can appreciate the difficulty. If it is obvious then then it is never particularly beautiful. But if it is subtle and clever and insightful and concise, that is the ground of beautiful mathematics.

The most likely reason is that you were never taught the basics to a point where they were intuitive. For example, if it takes you any effort at all to multiply 1-digit numbers, it will take you much longer to learn how to factor or multiply equations like (x + 3)(x - 5), which in turn makes it much more difficult to do Calculus, etc.  So if you're having a hard time with some part of Math, check how easily and intuitively you can answer problems from the previous year's material. Getting to the point where that's as easy as 1+2 = 3 is necessary for learning the next step.

The most fascinating of all knowledge and the most phobia generating subject is Mathematics. It is the improper introduction of maths that leaves many children with a lifelong aversion for the subject. Maths is often very poorly taught by us teachers, who themselves don’t have a strong passion or a deep appreciation for it. Most of us focus on and cater to the question “What”? and by doing so we conveniently avoid and ignore the fundamental question which is “WHY”? Also, the books in mathematics are generally written from the mathematician’s perspective. The beauty and spirit of mathematics are indeed in its freedom and abstraction but a child at an early age isn’t expected to understand it. Often, which is almost always, it is left to the students to comprehend the real-life applications of mathematics and somehow find beauty and joy in it, on their own. In words of acclaimed Indian mathematician, Shakuntala Devi students abhor maths because of the wrong approach and because it is looked as a subject. The intimidating, imagination less, uninteresting computation exercises and formula-based learning that go by the name of math is a horrible experience for the students. And when they struggle, they begin to dread math, and eventually, we lose thousands of students who could be the scientists and engineers of tomorrow. If we reflect and take more time to ground them in the basics, we can turn them on to maths.
